QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: GUARD DOG

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence advise the House of the outcome of the review by the Royal Australian Air Force of its decision on the future of the RAAF guard dog which is well known by the nickname Sheriff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has been assiduous in raising this issue with me over some period. He has obliged me in the course of his representations to examine RAAF policy on the release of dogs it has trained to be guard dogs, particularly at what point of time it is prepared to consider their release into the general community. My first conclusion of that review is that I shall never review a decision on a dog again. My second conclusion is that the policy the RAAF has in relation to the dogs is appropriate, given the nature of the animals and the consequences to the general community were those animals to be prematurely released into it. The evaluation processes of the RAAF are perfectly acceptable as far as those dogs are concerned. It needs to be borne in mind that it is all very well to receive pressures from one angle in regard to the future of these dogs, but there would be a very reasonable public reaction to releasing into the community dogs which could be considered to be dangerous by the people who had been responsible for their management.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised, after all that, by the Air Force that Sheriff is not to be put down but is to be retrained as a pool dog, that is, a dog that will work with a variety of handlers. So in that context Sheriff will not be destroyed. However, I support the Air Force's decision not to release the dog to its former handler, LAC Brendan Prendergast, on the grounds that Sheriff is still assessed as being very aggressive and has not lost the will to attack or bite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I have been Speaker I have, I think, lessened a little the rigidity of the rule relating to the acknowledgement of certain people present in the gallery. I have tried to do this in a sensible manner. What I will do is rather unusual, and the gentleman I am going to mention will know how unusual it is. After many years in the Press gallery, for the first time we have present in the Speaker's gallery Mr Alan Reid who has reported the proceedings of this Parliament for so long. I guess that many of us have probably disagreed with Alan's reporting from time to time, but we have all treated him with the greatest of respect for the years of service he has given to this Parliament from the Press gallery. Alan, we are glad you are able to join us.

—I ask the Treasurer: Why will farmers, regardless of when they purchased farms, suffer limitations to the income losses they can offset against off-farm income when investors in real estate will be able to retain the benefits of negative gearing on properties purchased up to 17 July 1985? Further, why will farmers have limitations imposed on them when the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd can offset losses in its steel division against losses in other divisions? Further, why have farmers been singled out when owners of multiple retail businesses, for example, are able to offset their losses? Finally, why is the Government continuing to discriminate against the farming sector of this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole premise of the question is basically unsound. The fact is that someone who relies 100 per cent upon farm income is not affected at all, and that is the position of most farmers. Members of the National Party, who for years have masqueraded as the protectors and defenders of the farming interests of this country, ought to understand that someone relying on a farm income is not affected by this measure at all. The reason that there is quarantining is not to discriminate against the farm sector. We have made a commensurate discrimination against the property sector by virtue of the fact that these are areas of tax sheltering: Negative gearing in property and farm losses incurred by Pitt Street farmers. For years high income people who have been receiving their income predominantly away from the farm sector have been allowed to offset losses on farms where they have in many respects not really attempted to establish a firm agricultural base or a substantial agricultural income. Rather, they have written off capital and running costs against their other non-farm income for the purposes of securing, over time, a capital gain.

ANSWER.PARA: What this has done to the farm sector is to drive up land prices in some areas to the clear disbenefit of genuine farmers who have been trying to buy land and aggregate properties and who are now carrying substantial mortgages around their necks because the coalition parties for 30 years allowed the people they represent, very high income earners, to walk through the 60c tax rate by leaving all these loopholes in the tax system, one of the most glaring of which is tax sheltering.

The honourable gentleman asked me a question which I answered last week. Had he been listening he would have got the answer, that is, that any losses prior to 1986-87 are not lost. They can be carried forward. Indeed, any losses that accrue even after the introduction of this measure can be carried forward. They are not lost. In terms of offsets for people who are in a genuine farming position and seek some offset of their income or some complement to their income from a non-farm source, there are two tests. The first allows for full loss of non-farm income up to $15,000, with a partial loss to $30,000. Of course, where the property is owned and operated by a husband and wife there are two sets of such offsets in respect of the $15,000 and $30,000 limits for both taxpayers. The other test is the aggregate of five years under which farmers can write off losses against non-farm income up to the aggregate of the previous five years net farm income. So genuine farmers who are receiving some off-farm income to complement their farm income will be protected by that measure.

In respect of averaging, I made it clear last week that at the moment the current averaging provisions allow for up to $5,000 of non-farm income to be included and this will now be increased to $15,000. This will save the farming community $20m, so most farmers will be advantaged very much by the averaging provisions. The other obvious point is that all farmers will benefit from the reduction in marginal rates of tax. That is a benefit which will apply to the whole farm community and the whole farming sector.

I find this question somewhat interesting, bearing in mind that the Leader of the National Party of Australia sprang to his feet last Friday to say that I should not be answering questions on taxation in Parliament. When the honourable member for Newcastle asked me a question, the right honourable gentleman said:
The tax reform package is currently under debate and legislation is before the Parliament. It is not proper under our Standing Orders for such matters to be canvassed at Question Time.

I have let him off the hook by standing up and answering. I could have made him look an absolute mug by sitting here for a week. With his big mouth open, in came the right honourable member for New England trying to protect the Opposition's hopeless position on taxation by denying a questioner on this side of the House the right to a question. As I have answered his colleague's question, I shall now go on to answer the question that I was prevented from answering last Friday by the Leader of the National Party. That question by the honourable member for Newcastle related to a statement by the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the Treasurer that, while the rule of relevance is very wide at Question Time, his answer should be relevant to the original question.
—It is, Mr Speaker. The original question was:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Treasurer advise the House whether the Government has finalised its taxation reform package? How does the Government's progress in this area compare with--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I would be delighted if the Treasurer wanted to answer specific questions asked within our Standing Orders. He has just had submitted that this particular answer is not relevant and as it is not relevant it is contrary to the Standing Orders. If he wishes to get one of his colleagues to ask a question on a matter that is within the Standing Orders, that is a different proposition altogether.

—Order! There are two aspects here. The matter which occurred on Friday was concluded before I was able to give a ruling within the Standing Orders and I would have ruled that the question was proper. The caution I gave the Treasurer today was that I trusted that in taking up the extension of that question he would relate it to the question asked today by the honourable member for Page. If he does so, the relevance applies.

—The relevance is that the Government's tax policy is thought through, well conceived, announced, and will be implemented. The honourable member for Page asked me a question in relation to the Government's tax policy, as did the honourable member for Newcastle. What is entirely obvious is that the Opposition has no such coherence in taxation policy, has not got a clue about where it is going in respect of taxation policy, and when Senator Messner, the taxation spokesman for the Opposition, last week gave an interview to Louise Dodson in the Australian Financial Review he gave a very interesting summary of what he believed Opposition tax policy should be. I took him up on the point about his supporting a capital gains tax, with an extension of section 26AAA and other matters. I have had a reply, in a manner of speaking, from Senator Messner, who referred in the Senate to my hysterical imaginings about his discussions on section 26AAA and talked about sinister connotations being put on his views. He also said that we needed a modification to section 26AAA. His whole statement dealt with making senseless points about modification. It is a play on words whether one is dealing with a modification of an existing tax policy or a change. When is a change a modification and when is a modification a change?

ANSWER.PARA: The long and the short of it is, basically, that the Opposition believes in having a capital gains tax based on section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Senator Messner, in the Opposition's so-called secret document, goes on to say that on equity grounds speculative windfall gains such as lottery wins ought logically to have been included in a capital gains tax. So he proposed to take the whole concept of capital gains taxation even further than the Government has taken it. He proposes not only simply to tax real gains and wash from the calculations the inflationary impact but also to adopt a section 26AAA approach to medium term capital taxation on the basis of the full nominal gain being taxed at the full marginal rates and applying it to lottery wins and everything else. So Senator Messner has made quite clear what Opposition tax policy is. He has walked away from his Leader on any views he might have. When I picked him up on these points in the Parliament he scurried away to the Senate and said he had been misrepresented.

The fact of the matter is that the Opposition has a policy which is totally ultra vires that expressed for years by the Leader of the Opposition. It has no thought-through position on taxation, as it has not on wages or public policy generally. What becomes patently obvious is that over time all that the Opposition will do is cavil and carp at the Government's policies while offering no constructive alternative except to try to slither behind a mealy-mouthed attack on the Government on capital gains, while it has a capital gains tax in the offing and in the making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the Treasurer wind up his answer.

—All that we ask is that there be no more double standards from the Opposition on a capital gains tax when it is harbouring proposals to have a capital gains tax-a pernicious, vicious and savage tax at full marginal rates on full nominal gains. Nothing Senator Messner has said will let him off the hook. He has said that the Liberal Party wants a capital gains tax. Therefore, how dare the Opposition criticise honourable members on this side of the House for proposing a capital gains tax when it is contemplating such a tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Acting Prime Minister see in this morning's Australian Financial Review an article headed: `States urge banks to take softer line towards customers hurt by card fraud'? I ask whether the Minister saw a comment in that article which, with regard to the recent meeting of Consumer Affairs Ministers, referred to:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . expressions of dissatisfaction about the Commonwealth Government's progress on the problem.
The latest indication is that the Commonwealth would take another 18 months before some legislation is in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is allowed to use a reasonable amount of information to make his question intelligible, but he is going beyond the bounds in giving a long quotation. I ask him to come to his question.

—In view of the importance of this matter, will the Minister say whether this is true and advise the House as to the progress being made in this important matter of setting up legal rules governing the use of and fraud on credit cards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has formed an inter-departmental committee which also comprises observers if not representatives from State governments to talk about the question of fraud in relation to the electronic transfer of funds. There have been a number of discussions. I did not attend the last ministerial meeting of Consumer Affairs Ministers, but I am aware that consumers are very concerned that fraud could be perpetrated and that they would be held responsible. The State governments are quite right in saying that they also have a responsibility, particularly as it relates to building societies and credit unions which are also involved in what is called electronic transfer of funds. It is incorrect for the article to suggest that the Commonwealth is not interested. It is incorrect to suggest that the Commonwealth would delay the matter. The issue at present is that there is no legislation which protects consumers involved in fraud by this method of transfer of funds. Naturally, the banks are also concerned and are perhaps reluctant to suggest that there could be a liability on them. One has to look at the balance of the situation. The consumer has to be protected and, should the consumer not be protected, those who would be liable have to be assured that a fraud has been perpetrated. In other words, with a card system, someone could use a card and, although the normal customer may not be using the card, it may not necessarily be a fraud. There is that difficulty. It is important that we have protective devices for the consumer.

ANSWER.PARA: It is novel in the sense that this type of crime is well known across the world and is increasing. It requires a co-operative effort between the Commonwealth and the States. I am happy to say that the IDC established by the Treasurer is working towards that end. I am anxious that, if a regime can be established, we should have legislation at the earliest opportunity to guarantee that all bona fide customers or consumers will be compensated in the normal way when such fraud has been perpetrated. At present, as the honourable gentleman knows, if fraud can be established with respect to cheques and other mechanisms, the liability is not on the customer or the consumer. That is the issue here. The question is whether there can be some method whereby a customer could be deemed to be guilty of negligence in allowing the card to pass out of his or her hands. I am sure that the matter can be dealt with effectively. It will require advice from both the Federal Government and State governments as to how best it can be done. It is agreed by all Ministers that it is better to have uniform legislation and I am anxious for that uniform legislation to be introduced at the earliest opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In light of the fact that up to 1,000 people have now lost their jobs in the restaurant and catering industry in Queensland alone in the past fortnight, and that concern has been expressed by a number of industries especially in the primary sector at the effects of the termination of entertainment expenses, can the Minister advise what will be the total saving to revenue of this measure? Will this be counteracted by the loss of income tax, excise and other receipts? Is the Treasurer prepared to re-examine his proposals to try to determine a better system whereby tax deductibility may be allowed for legitimate entertainment expenses in restaurants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I answer this one, Ian?
—Yes, Paul.
—This one is all right, is it?
—Within reasonable time constraints, yes.

—I will just say this about the Liberal Party of Australia: For 25 years in this Parliament members of the Liberal Party have worked hot to work out how their people could dodge the 60 per cent rate by leaving all of these loopholes in the tax system. They never worried about all the tax shelters; they kept putting more in because they always knew that, as people's incomes were inflated through the tax scales, as the burden fell more and more substantially on low and middle income earners, the people they represented would not have to pay because they had worked out all the loopholes in the system. That is why they are now smarting. The fact is that we have actually removed the opportunities for minimisation by cleaning up all of those tax shelters. There is now this interest about the entertainment sector which goes not simply to a minimisation of their income but actually even disturbs their lifestyle. They may even wear the effects on their income but they do not like it to disturb their lifestyle. They like having their lunch with the Commissioner of Taxation picking up 46 per cent of the bill.

ANSWER.PARA: One has to draw a very long bow in looking at the effects upon employment in the restaurant industry as last week we saw figures showing an employment growth of 56,000 people in one month. Honourable members opposite are talking about 1,000 people employed in the restaurant industry being affected. I do not know whether they are right about that or not. I notice that another economic rationalist at the back of the chamber is chipping in with his tuppence worth about free meals. It is too early to say what the impact will be on employment in the restaurant industry. I am told that it may affect some restaurants differently from others and that, so far, some restaurants are not affected by the measures at all. Some seem to have been affected but not as greatly as they feared. Making premature judgments and relying on assessments by analysis organisations which have produced reports with horrendous employment effects are hardly the sorts of things for the Parliament to take notice of. We are seeing a very strong employment growth in the economy at the moment. If there is any displacement in this sector it can be taken up elsewhere.

There is no case for any one sector of commerce in this country having its employment or its prosperity underpinned by a tax shelter. Of course, if we provide tax concessions for any one sector of commerce versus another, that sector will enjoy more prosperity relative to other sectors of the economy. That is very clear; we can see it from the proliferation in the number of restaurants over the last decade or so. I have very grave reservations as to whether entertainment should ever have been allowed as a deduction in the tax system. Given the fact that it has been widely abused and exploited in the shameless way in which it has, I think the cries of a lot of people in the industry are cries for the continuation of a position of privilege which they enjoyed.

I make it quite clear that this does not affect the whole industry. It certainly affects business meals, drinks, cocktail parties, staff functions, et cetera; but conventions and conferences at which meals are not in the category of entertainment are still deductible. Therefore, the convention industry, which is growing in this country as convention facilities are being made available, will still have meals as a deductible expense, as indeed will be the case with staff canteens and the like. This notion that the removal of the tax deductibility of restaurant meals will devastate this whole component of the leisure industry, particularly the convention industry, is simply not true. We will have to wait for some time yet to see what the full employment consequences will be in this industry. Again, it can only encourage a change within the community for those people who wish to have their meals out by requiring them to go to places where they can afford to go without deducting it from their taxable income.

I suggest to the honourable member that he regard the change as a need to make the tax system more fair, more equitable and more efficient. In that case we will see a more dynamic economy with more employment growth. What has been a subsidy to one industry will end up being a benefit to the whole economy and with a benefit to the whole economy, we will simply see a far stronger economy and more aggregate employment. So the honourable member's fears about employment losses in the restaurant industry ought to be weighed against that fact.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE ASSOCIATION: PROPOSED INDUSTRIAL ACTION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Special Minister of State aware of threatened industrial action by the Australian Federal Police Association which includes the threat not to enforce the traffic laws in Canberra? Will the Minister meet with the Association to discuss the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fraser for his question. Yes, I am aware of the matters raised by the Canberra branch of the Australian Federal Police Association. In the last couple of weeks I had occasion to address the national conference of the Association and raised some of the matters which it now wishes to discuss with me, including the question of police resources as it affects the Australian Capital Territory as well as the question I raised regarding lateral recruitment into the Australian Federal Police. I have met with members of the newly elected executive of the AFPA since that conference last week and it was intended that I meet with them again next week in Adelaide, but I understand that arrangements are to be made that I will meet them here.

ANSWER.PARA: I can tell the honourable member for Fraser that I can understand the frustration of some of the people in the Australian Capital Territory, perhaps as a result of meeting with members of the national executive on an agenda which deals with matters basically concerning policing operations outside the Australian Capital Territory. Because of the demands of the work load outside Canberra there has been a tendency for people within the Australian Capital Territory to have the impression that perhaps it was getting a lower priority. This has not been the case. As I said to the Parliament earlier, in a comparison with the major States the Australian Capital Territory is only second after South Australia in having police per head of population available to it; so it is in a very good position compared with the States and there has not been any tendency by either the Fraser Government or this Government to deplete the police resources available to Canberra.

I want to reiterate that the demands made on the Australian Federal Police over the last six years, since its emergence in that concept, have changed very dramatically and most of the demands made on the Commonwealth law enforcement agency have been outside Canberra-in the major criminal and white collar crime areas. Looking ahead at what sort of operations the police would have in Australia, we would have to predict that that is where the growth will continue to be. I raised the question of lateral recruitment not on the basis that the Government had made a decision in conjunction with the Commission that this is what we were going to do but rather on the basis that the Association ought to think about these matters, because obviously in dealing with some of the sophisticated crime that is operating in Australia at the moment there may be a need for the Government to discuss with the Association the need to bring more professional people into the police to deal with these questions.

Any of the matters which I raised at the Association conference can be discussed with the Association from the conceptual stage before any decision is taken. I can also reassure both the honourable member for Fraser and the honourable member for Canberra, who were good enough to lead a delegation to me last week of concerned people in the community, that whenever matters concerning Canberra are on the agenda of the national executive of the Association, I have asked it to make sure that people from the Canberra branch of the Association are present on that delegation. In dealing with these matters I do not think there is any reason why the local branch of the Association should be calling for industrial action. The door has been open for the negotiations to take place on all of these matters. I would just like the Parliament and the Canberra branch of the Association to understand that the decisions on the operation of the Federal Police are not a matter for the Minister, but are a matter for the Commissioner, and he will continue to make them in terms of the resources that are made available to the Australian Federal Police.

It may be of interest to honourable members to know that the police college at which the recruits are taken in, at Weston, in Canberra, will be working at capacity from January 1986 until June 1986, using up all the recruits that will be made available to it as a result of the $10m promised to it from the last election by the Prime Minister. So I suggest to the members of the Association who are thinking of taking industrial action that these matters should be set aside until discussions are held between the Association, which includes this branch, and me.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUILDING CONSTRUCTION EMPLOYEES AND BUILDERS LABOURERS FEDERATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What is he doing to curb the activities of organisers of the Builders Labourers Federation who have black-banned non-unionist contractors from building work in my electorate and have threatened, and forced union levies upon, both work experience students and their employers? Will he ensure that these valuable work experience programs are able to continue without this thuggery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the specific examples that the honourable member raises in his question but I am aware of the general issue he raises. Let me say first that the Builders Labourers Federation has engaged in various activities which this Government has criticised. As a result, we have taken unprecedented action to try to eradicate those practices and, in particular, have taken action against the Federation as such to remove it from the industrial relations system.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the question of forcing people on work experience or job creation programs to become members of the union and to pay union fees, I took up that matter with the Australian Council of Trade Unions some time ago. The ACTU was unable to get the BLF to change its practices to any substantial degree. It is a matter which continues to concern me. I understand that various people who have been unemployed for a long time and have got a job in the building industry have been faced with the demand immediately to pay a very substantial amount of union fees-for half a year or so, which in the case of the BLF is well over $100. That is an amount of money which many people cannot find easily when they have been unemployed for a long period. It is a matter which concerns me very much. I will continue to do my best to change that, but I suspect that the only real way by which we will change it is to take that fundamental action against the BLF in which we are engaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Trade seen the allegation that the foreign tax credit system proposed by the Government would discourage Australian investment in South East Asia and disadvantage Australia in its trade with China?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen such references-that if the Government proceeded with its decision in relation to the foreign tax credit system, this would disadvantage Australia's trade performance, particularly in the region. It is important to point out that in the Treasurer's statement of 19 September he indicated that in proceeding with the foreign tax credit system the Government would take appropriate measures to recognise the position of Australian investment in regional countries. The Government wants to encourage Australian investment in those areas where it will encourage trade between Australia and those developing countries.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of Australian companies have invested in the region and those investments have been important in encouraging and fortifying the trade relationships between Australia and those countries. I think there has been an attempt to make some mischief with this announcement. I indicate, as did the Treasurer on 19 September, that we are alert to these concerns and, well before the introduction of this new scheme foreshadowed for July next year, we will have an opportunity to consider those on a case by case basis.

This reference was made by the Leader of the Opposition in a speech to the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce, a speech which was distinguished only by the extent of the gross inaccuracies contained in it. This particular inaccuracy was probably one of the most glaring of all. One always has a choice when one is considering the inaccuracies to which the Leader of the Opposition puts his name. His inaccuracies can be either deliberate misrepresentations of the kind for which he is famous-a particular example of that was his deliberate misrepresentation at the time of the 1983 election, when he withheld from the Australian public the prospect of the $9.6 billion deficit for Australia in 1983-84-or they can be further evidence of his compulsive misery. Time and time again the Leader of the Opposition has made predictions of dire prospects for the Australian economy, all of which have turned out to be untrue. Of course, it has been a matter of monumental disappointment for the Leader of the Opposition that his prophecies of doom for the Australian economy have not been realised and that, instead, the Australian economy is doing infinitely better; in fact, it has put into the shade completely the Australian economy's performance during the time when he had the task of determining economic policy.

Or, alternatively, the third choice that one has when confronted with inaccuracies from the Leader of the Opposition is that he is just plain wrong. Of course, there have been so many occasions on which the Leader of the Opposition, when he was Treasurer, was just plain wrong. It is perfectly clear that the rest of the members of the Opposition have a very short recall of memory when it comes to his performance. But it is important to remember that in each of the five Budgets for which he was responsible, expenditure outlays were in excess of those predicted at Budget time. If one goes to the question of deficit projections, one finds that he was wrong on three out of five occasions. If one goes to the question of predictions of unemployment, one finds that he was wildly wrong on most occasions.

The only point I want to make is that in that speech, which, as I say, was celebrated only by the extent of the inaccuracies within it, the Leader of the Opposition made certain undertakings about what a government led by him would do in the area of taxation. One has only to look at his record when he had the opportunity to do things, to realise that one should take absolutely no account of what he says. He has demonstrated time and again that in office and out of office he is totally unreliable.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MAJOR WESTERN INDUSTRIAL POWERS: SUMMIT CONFERENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Science. Is it a fact that Australia has, until now, not been invited to attend a summit conference of the seven major Western industrial powers? Is it also a fact that Australia will be attending the Ottawa summit next week? If so, will the Minister provide details?

—The answer to all three questions is yes. The Ottawa summit of 20-21 October is the sequel to the conference of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development held in Venice in April 1985, where Ministers from the 24 nations discussed technology and job creation. My invitation to this conference was at the instance of Japan, the United States, Canada and Italy. It is to be hoped that this will be a forerunner of Australia's permanent representation at northern summit conferences. The meeting will consider policies for promoting promising technologies and industries, the role of government vis-a-vis industry and industrial research and development innovation, and planning and co-ordination of science and research. I have been asked to lead the discussion on the first of these subjects. The invitation is also a confirmation of the old adage about prophets not being without honour.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that petrol pricing in this country is a real mess? Is the Minister aware that the Prime Minister said that he would reduce the price of petrol? Is the Minister aware that petrol prices have increased by about 10c to 12c a litre since his Government came to office?
—Nonsense!

—No, it is not damned nonsense; it is an absolute fact. Is the Minister aware that the disparity in the price of petrol throughout this country is having a very dampening effect on the rural economy and also on States such as Tasmania, in which people are paying 60c a litre--
—Order! The honourable member must come to the point of his question.

—I am coming to the point now with a positive request. Will the Minister give consideration to the formation of a select committee or a joint committee, comprising Labor, Liberal and National Party members, to look into the price of petrol and get it away from the bureaucrats, get it away from the judges--

—Our prices were lower than those of the United States in April. Considering that the United States is such a prodigious producer, the fact that our metropolitan prices were so low was a great tribute to the policies of this Government overall. There is no question that the enormous variation in petrol pricing, as honourable members well know, is due to the huge size of our country, the dispersal of its population and the inevitable high distribution costs in between. These problems have not arisen under this Government. They are endemic problems. As long as we have an industrialised economy based on the distribution of fuel we will have enormous variations in fuel costs because of distance. It seems to me that that is not a problem that can be overturned by setting up a conference or a committee, no matter how well intentioned. Essentially, that would mean redistributing the burden so that the great bulk of urban petrol consumers would be paying more in order to subsidise the delivery costs in the bush. I hear Telecom Australia cited by an honourable member as an example. That is an absolutely fundamental question that would need to be looked at in a Budget context. As I say, I am prepared to refer the honourable member's question to Senator Gareth Evans for his comment, but basically I do not think it will change the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the Opposition is obliged to raise a matter which irks the world's greatest Treasurer no end:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuing escalation of costs to home owners, small business and rural industries arising from the Government's high interest rate policy.

New home owners will be the hardest hit because they have to face up to the widening deposit gap. Our argument is with people who make promises and do not deliver. Our argument is with those who claim that they have the world's best economic policy yet refuse to acknowledge glaring defects in that policy.

That is what we hold the Government to. Before the election it promised a drop in interest rates. After the election it continued to say that there would be a drop in interest rates. As recently as April the Prime Minister, while blaming irrational markets for an increase in interest rates, said that there would still be a drop. That is what we were promised. We compare that with a rise to 18 1/2 per cent in the prime rate and an increase of 2 per cent for home borrowings since then, with increases of $10 a week for modest home owners.

What about the economic policy that we are talking about? Just how good is it when interest rates are at their highest real levels since the Great Depression? How good is it when home owners, small businesses and farmers are really hurting from the cost effects of high interest rates? How good is it when our inflation rate is higher than those of our trading partners and when our international competitiveness is threatened? How good is it when the dollar is still shaky months after the devaluation which was supposed to put us back into the ring?

Today we got the September balance of payments figures. Once again, despite the fact that we have the world's greatest Treasurer and the world's greatest economic policy, the figures are very bad. There has been a further deterioriation in the balance of payments at a time when we ought to be seeing some benefit accruing from the devaluation earlier this year. Both the balance of trade and current account positions moved further into deficit in September. For the first three months of this financial year the current account deficit was $3,345m, well up on the deficit for the same period last year. So it looks as though we are headed for a current account deficit this financial year which will surpass last year's historically high level.

What is of particular concern is that the benefits of the competitive advantage which should have been expected to flow from the massive devaluation of the dollar earlier this year have not yet materialised. In fact, our trading performance has continued to deteriorate, with a marginal decline in imports being more than offset by an 11 per cent decline in the value of our exports while at the same time our inflation performance has worsened against that of our major trading partners. Our balance of payments performance so far, combined with our massive overseas debt, will be further bad news for interest rates because, in order to avoid further downward pressure on our exchange rate, the Government has been forced to keep interest rates at exorbitant levels. If the dollar falls much further-it has been very shaky against the trade weighted index-the Government will have to go cap in hand once again to the Australian Council of Trade Unions to seek further wage discounting or risk a further intensification of inflationary pressures. But high interest rates themselves feed back into the economy causing economic damage as their costs go through into wages through automatic wage indexation.

This Government has to face up to two things. The first is the fact that it promised in the election campaign, and again this year, that interest rates would fall. This Government is very good at telling us how good its economic management is. It is very good at telling us what the benefits are. It told us what the benefits were going to be before the election and those benefits have not materialised. But what is worse than that, the overseas position is still deteriorating, despite the effects we should have got from devaluation, and the interest rate regime would seem to have to continue for months ahead. My question to the Treasurer is this: In view of the promises that he and the Prime Minister made to the Australian people, just when will we see interest rates coming down? This basic ingredient of a healthy economy, that is, a reasonable rate of interest, must come along soon, otherwise the whole of the accord will come tumbling round the Treasurer's ears. I repeat my question to the Treasurer: Just when will the high interest rate regime be stopped? Just when will interest rates fall in the way that he and the Prime Minister so clearly indicated to the Australian people before and after the election?

We want to maximise employment opportunities in the economy and in the maximisation of those opportunities we want to maximise growth. The 1984 average farm debt of around $31,000 was almost exactly matched by liquid assets of a similar amount. Hence, on average, farmers gain as much as they lose from interest rate increases. Of course, this average hides relatively small pockets of farmers who are experiencing problems. This Government is certainly very alarmed about the problems that certain industries are facing. However, these problems tend to be related to the commodities concerned. The major problems at present are in the areas of horticulture, rice, sugar and Western Australian wheat farming, which the honourable member for Gwydir mentioned. It is obvious from this list that the major difficulty is with low returns as much as with high interest rates. Perhaps low returns are having a bigger effect than high interest rates and the real problem is in low returns.

It is true that rural indebtedness has increased, possibly by around 10 per cent in 1984-85, which would bring the total debt of the rural sector to around $6,500m. A significant proportion of this increase would reflect the result in producers borrowing to finance expansion. Farmers had debt problems under the reign of the present Leader of the Opposition as Treasurer and were borrowing just to hang on. Today, right throughout the economy, people are borrowing money, even at high interest rates, to invest and expand. That is the difference with the economy at present.

Let us look at some of the strong points of the economy. Economic growth fell by 0.6 per cent in 1982-83 but increased by 4.9 per cent in 1983-84 and by 4.6 per cent in 1984-85. Non-farm gross domestic product grew by 5 per cent in 1984-85. Economic growth averaged only 2.1 per cent a year under the Liberals. It is averaging close to 5 per cent under Labor. Hence, it is quite obvious that there are pressures to borrow money, not, as used to be the case, for farming and business communities to hang on. Today they are borrowing money to invest, to develop their economies, to expand. Why should they want to do so? In regard to consumption, retail sales continue to rise strongly, increasing by 4.3 per cent in the July quarter of 1985 to being 11.2 per cent higher than they were in the July quarter of 1984. From the April 1983 though, employment is up 481,200-well on target to meeting this Government's promise of creating 500,000 jobs within three years. The unemployment rate is down from 10.4 per cent in September 1983 to 8.1 per cent in September 1985. These figures clearly indicate that we have two elements working in the economy at present. One is the monetary policy which the Government is sticking to and which has been applauded throughout the economy. This is no doubt affecting interest rates, but in the long term I am sure that the Australian people will understand that this is the policy they elected this Government to carry out. We need only to look at the editorial in the Australian of 10 March 1983 to see what was being said at the time of the election and what the people of Australia want. I will read part of it in this debate:

The former prime minister, Mr Fraser, and his colleagues were elected to government with an overwhelming majority on December 13, 1975, on their own argument that they were demonstrably better economic and financial managers than the previous . . . government. In their seven years and 82 days in office they failed, dismally, in living up to those claims . . .

As prime minister, Mr Fraser must take much of the blame for the failure of his government's economic policies. But he cannot be expected to shoulder all the responsibility for the government's inability-or unwillingness-to pursue its economic and financial objectives.

Much of it must also be laid at the door of his treasurer for five years, Mr John Howard, who was responsible for framing, with Treasury advice, the last five Budgets of the Fraser government. It will take a long time for him to live down his ministerial legacy of huge Budget deficits this year and next.

What is required now is a prime minister and treasurer who know exactly what the deficit is and know what to do about it. It is up to Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, from their formal assumption of office tomorrow, to take on the tough job of repairing the damage to the Government's finances and the economy, and set the country on the road to recovery.

That is what this debate today is about. Members of the Opposition come in here bleating about interest rates without any policy of their own. As I mentioned at the start, they have three factions-the agrarian socialists, the Liberal dries and the Liberal wets. None of them knew which direction they wanted to go in those days when they should have learned the lessons that the Australian newspaper talked about so effectively.

In their speeches on the matter of public importance today honourable members opposite also said that interest rates were having a detrimental effect on the housing sector. Let us look at some of the figures. Between the trough in the March quarter 1983 to the June quarter 1985, real private dwelling investment rose by 40.4 per cent. That is a massive increase in investment. It has happened at a time when the Opposition is trying to tell us that there is doom and gloom about, that people are not prepared to invest, that people are not confident of the economy in Australia and that interest rates are too high. When this country gets fully mobile, when we get interest rates and the economy back into kilter with a lower inflation rate, we will see some real figures, but these are quite impressive as they are. In 1984-85 housing commencements numbered 152,000, the highest level since 1973-74. The lowest levels of commencement we saw for a long time were at the end of the reign of the Fraser Government. In the three months to August 1985 the number of approvals rose by 1.2 per cent.

Let us go to one of the areas that the honourable member for Mackellar and his Leader, the honourable member for Bennelong, used to claim they represented-the private business area. Real private business fixed investment recovered in 1984-85 by 4 per cent. The Statistician showed that, in current prices, investment expectations are 11 per cent higher for 1985 and 1986. In real terms we expect growth to be a little higher than last year. Is this a sign of a problem in the economy or that there is such drastic doom and gloom about, as mentioned by the honourable member for Mackellar and the honourable member for Gwydir? It certainly is not, and I am sure that this Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as stated in the Australian editorial I quoted previously, knew exactly what the deficit was and what to do about that sort of thing. We have had a clear indication from the time that that was printed in 1983 through to today that the Government is on the correct course. The figures indicate that the Government is on the correct course and there is certainly no doubt as to what the Government is on about. I conclude by going back to a report by the Reserve Bank of 30 June 1981. I quote one small section from its comments on policy-this was at a time when the honourable member for Bennelong was in charge:

Growth in money and credit in 1980-81 was too rapid, even taking into account that growth and output were stronger than expected. The outcome cannot be viewed independently of events in preceding years. Experience in the last three years has demonstrated weaknesses in the way policy has been implemented.
The Reserve Bank was quite adamant at that stage that the honourable member for Gwydir and the Liberal dries as we call them--
