That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill 1985 is a machinery Bill to make provision for financing of the Budget deficit in 1985-86 and subsequent years. Unfortunately, in some respects a government cannot overspend from Consolidated Revenue; so where the Parliament authorises expenditures that would cause the equivalent of an overdraft on the Consolidated Revenue Fund, the Government must borrow to meet the excess expenditure. It is just the same as in a household. If one has not enough money in one's bank account and outlays are higher than what is there, one has to borrow some money. This Bill makes arrangements for the Government to borrow. Previously there used to be an annual Loan Bill to handle this situation for all circumstances arising during a financial year. This Bill has been drafted as standing legislation rather than annual legislation to remove the necessity to pass legislation annually. As the Bill does not itself authorise expenditure but merely creates a mechanism whereby expenditures authorised by other legislation can be made, the Opposition does not object to the concept of standing legislation. It merely improves the efficiency of the Parliament. We therefore support the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are concerned about, however, is the level of borrowing required under the present Government's policies and the borrowing that this Bill enables. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) continues to shower himself with congratulations and self-praise. If one were to listen to all that without looking at the underlying figures, one might be somewhat taken in, but there is a very substantial increase in government spending under the Hawke Government leading to additional debt. The average real increase in government spending under the Hawke Government is still 4.9 per cent per year, which is more than double that of the average of the Fraser years. Something that is forgotten in the heat of debate is that the Fraser Government had a lower percentage increase in real terms over its seven years on average than any government before or since. That is something well worth saying because a lot of nonsense is talked about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well worth repeating.

—That is true. Incidentally, if I may say so in the same vein, it also had a lower rate of unemployment in six of its seven years than the Hawke Government has had since. What ought to be taken into account in looking at those figures is that that final year was a year of very grave international recession and drought within Australia. There were very exceptional conditions. When the Government congratulates itself on its present level of unemployment-about 8 per cent-it is really a shocking performance when one considers the alleged growth that has occurred over the years that have gone since. As a result of this extra spending, 750,000 pay as you earn taxpayers will move into higher tax brackets this year and 500,000 of them will go into the 46c rate. In the recent package they were promised some relief from this, starting in September of next year and then again in July of 1987. We will see whether there is any money available to pay for those promises.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the present Treasurer per capita overseas debt has risen from $1,571 in June 1983 to $3,326 in June 1985. In other words, to look at it in a personal way, in June 1983 every individual-man, woman and child-had borrowed $1,571 overseas and in June 1985 that had risen to $3,326 per person. That is a rather frightening thought. If one sees a baby in a pram these days, one knows that attached to that baby's head is an overseas debt of no less than $3,326 before the child has even been to school. That is very serious. The overseas debt under this Government has risen over that same period of two years from 14.6 per cent to 25.1 per cent of our gross domestic product. More than a quarter of everything we produce in a year goes to service our overseas debt, and that is a pretty frightening figure. The public sector component of that debt has risen from $864 a head in June 1983 to $1,670 a head in 1985; it has doubled. Despite the fact that the economy is supposed to have grown and despite the fact that we are supposed to have the best economic managers in the world our public sector overseas debt, which was $864 a head two years ago, is now $1,670 a head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty per cent more than in the United States.

—Yes, as the honourable member for Denison so correctly says, it is 50 per cent more than in the United States. It is said that the United States has a very high level of debt at the moment, and historically it has, but ours is double that level.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, when one has debt like this one has to pay interest on it. One also has to repay capital according to the obligations in the original arrangements. Australia's external debt servicing obligations, expressed as the ratio of interest payments and contractually due capital repayments to exports of goods and services, rose from 8.3 per cent of GDP in 1979-80 to 33.6 per cent in 1984-85. Let me explain that to honourable members. In order to get some idea of how much of one's overseas earnings one must pay out in order to service one's borrowings, one has what is called a debt servicing ratio. If one takes interest and capital together, then over the financial year just ended 33.6 per cent of our exports of goods and services had to be spent on repayment of capital under contract and interest. In other words, about one-third of everything we earned overseas in a year had to be paid out in interest payments and repayment of capital. If one is running a household and one is paying out one-third of after-tax income in servicing debts, one must be a little worried about how far one is going. Consequently, we as a nation must be very concerned about that.

There is another indicator called the public sector borrowing requirement. If one takes the total requirement of public bodies-Federal, State and local-to borrow money in order to meet spending that is not covered by current income, one sees that it is still 5.6 per cent of our gross domestic product, or almost 50 per cent greater than that of the United States. It is also much higher than that of most other industrialised countries. Australia's 5.6 per cent in 1986 compares with 3.8 per cent for the United States, 0.5 per cent for Japan, 1.3 per cent for West Germany, and 2.9 per cent for the United Kingdom. The only country that gets close to us is the rather profligate Canada, which has had pretty bad economic policies over a number of years. Its requirement is 5.5 per cent, but we are still higher than that at 5.6 per cent.

The deficit of about $5 billion in this year's Budget-it was put at $4.9 billion, but because of the deal done with the Australian Council of Trade Unions on wage discounting, some discounting of inflationary pressures due to devaluation was agreed to-means that the cumulative deficit in the first three Keating Budgets is $20 billion. This is more than the cumulative deficits for the seven Fraser Budgets. So in just three years this Government has chalked up deficits which are higher than those of all seven Fraser Budgets put together. It must be remembered that even if the Hawke Government achieves the $5 billion deficit this year, this outcome will still be higher than any deficit in the Fraser years and will be twice the average deficit levels during those seven years. In the light of all the whingeing that goes on in the House about how terrible the Fraser Government was, it is interesting to make these comparisons.

The Government has made much of its small increase in spending, but if one looks at the Budget Papers one sees that outlays in 1985-86 are expected to be 29.8 per cent of gross domestic product-the third highest level in Australia's history-and they were beaten only by the first two Hawke Budgets and equalled by the last big-spending Whitlam Budget. So, in effect, this is back to 1975 stuff here, which is quite interesting because there is a big difference between the rhetoric about economic performance and the actual figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't really believe this stuff?
—The figures are all in the Budget Papers, if the honourable member would like to look at them. Those Papers are prepared by the Treasury-
—I have the Budget Papers here.

—Certainly the honourable member will be able to check these figures out in the Budget Papers. The average real increase in the first three Hawke Budgets was 4.9 per cent, more than twice the average real increase in the seven Fraser Budgets of 2.2 per cent. Those figures are also available directly from the Treasurer's Budget Papers. That fact cannot be denied, even by the honourable member for Bendigo. If we look at the public debt, the Commonwealth's public debt interest bill, which does not include the States or the statutory authorities, will be a massive $6.724m in 1985-86-an increase of more than $1 billion over last year, or almost 19 per cent. So public debt interest is the largest individual item of spending after social security and payments to the States and local government. In other words, in this year's Budget we are spending more on interest costs than we are spending individually on defence, health and education. That is where we have got by this high spending policy. In fact, the interest charges have doubled in the three Keating Budgets from $3,378m in 1982-83 to the present level of $6,724m. Let me put that in terms that everyone can understand because this is a pretty frightening figure. The fact is that $6,724m interest costs-and people do not generally understand billions and millions-actually costs each individual taxpayer $20 a week. When one gets one's pay packet and looks at the pay slip, one should realise that $20 each week is contributed to interest charges alone. If a taxpayer is paying much higher interest rates on a home loan, on hire purchase payments and on Bankcard, which has just gone up to 21 per cent, and on all those other charges which have increased enormously over the past few months, despite the promises by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer before the election that they would reduce interest rates, he must realise that after paying his own private interest bill, an average of $20 a week over and above that goes to meet the Federal Government's interest bill. Then, of course, there are State and local government interest bills to pay on top of that. We have a pretty high overseas debt in this country at the moment, both private and public, and both of those are worrying.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the problems arising from these levels of debt? First, there is the question of the burden on the Budget of servicing public debt. If one is trying to construct a Budget and find funds to pay pensions, improve health services, which are a disaster at the moment, improve education and all those basic things we need, and trying to keep our soldiers, sailors and airmen properly paid, before any of that can be done $6.7 billion must be paid in interest charges. That is an obvious problem with inflationary effects as well. To the extent that money needs to be borrowed in Australia-in other words, there is not enough money on current account and it needs to be borrowed in order to pay off this debt and to meet costs-it places additional pressure on already high interest rates. Interest rates are very high at the moment-18 1/2 per cent at the prime rate and many interest rates for business are more than 20 per cent. If the Government is making additional demands, if it has to go out and borrow additional money as well, that will have an upward pressure on the general level of interest rates, and that has flow-on effects into the economy. If interest rates go up substantially the effect is felt on all costs, not just domestic costs. The effect is felt in interest rates on home loans, overdrafts, finance purchases and Bankcard and also on every interest charge that is placed on a business. Charges will go up for small business borrowings, borrowings on overdrafts for working capital, borrowings for investment in, say, new plant, an extra shop or any productive investment. If interest rates on such borrowings went up from 12 1/2 per cent to, say, 18 per cent or 20 per cent, as they have risen over the last year or so, that would push up costs and would also have the effect that one would not want to go ahead with new activities. It would ultimately have a very depressing effect on business investment.

The Treasurer has claimed that people are falling over themselves wanting to borrow money at 20 per cent in order to make investments. I simply do not see that happening around the traps. I do not see small businessmen in my electorate rushing out to borrow money at 20 per cent in order to push up their overall level of debt to a level which would make them go broke if there was any fall off in the economy. It is simply not happening, and this is a fiction of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is borrowing the money?

—Some of the people honourable members opposite are always attacking. When money is borrowed abroad the need to meet the interest and capital repayments on overseas debt, particularly when it is added to the present high level of private overseas borrowings, soaks up our overseas earnings. The balance of payments figures for September were released today. They are not very good. They show a further deterioration in our balance of payments; in other words, this month we have added substantially to our overall level of overseas borrowings and, therefore, we have added to our debt servicing and capital repayment commitments. That presents some very grave difficulties for economic management. In a word, this month's figures are crook. The Treasurer admitted earlier in the debate on the matter of public importance that the figures were crook, but he said that they were in line with what the Treasury forecast said they ought to be. That does not cut any ice with me. If the Treasury forecast says we will have crook figures and if they come out as crook, they are still crook and the overall position is not in any way diminished. Those figures are very bad.

SPEECH.PARA: How does that affect us? At the moment, it affects us in rather a serious way because for the first time in a very long time in Australia's history overseas lenders are beginning to question Australia's international credit rating. When the Western Australian Government recently wanted to borrow some money overseas, for the very first time overseas banks asked serious questions about the capacity of that Government to pay back that money. Those are the sorts of questions that governments in Australia have not had to face up to before because we have a treble A rating around the international borrowing traps. That was an interesting sign that people are beginning to worry about our overseas indebtedness and our capacity to meet our interest and capital repayments. They are beginning to question it.

There is a magazine called the Institutional Investor, which is widely read around the world by those investing in various economies. It recently conducted a survey of international banks to see how they rated the credit worthiness of various countries borrowing money on the international stage. The sad news from that survey, which was published a couple of weeks ago, is that Australia had slipped quite substantially in recent times and had been slipping since the Hawke Government came to power.

Although we had a devaluation in the Australian currency, which was supposed to give us the chance to improve our domestic economy, to push up local manufacturing, to replace imports and to give us a competitive advantage, it seems that the dollar is still suspect in international circles. In recent weeks, it has started once again to look shaky against the currencies of our trading partners. All this, combined with the additions to our overseas debt and the concern of international investors about our credit worthiness, gives us some domestic concern for our economy.

Of course, the Treasurer is in a rather difficult position because he has to try to keep up the value of the dollar. A further devaluation of the dollar would mean that import costs would rise and the extra costs would flow into the economy. It would have an inflationary effect on prices, which would go up internally. The consumer price index would reflect that increase. Under the automatic wage indexation provisions of the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions prices and incomes accord, the unions would expect an automatic increase because prices had gone up, even though the only reason for their going up would be the higher cost of imports due to devaluation.

This all happened a few months ago and the Treasurer had the very difficult job of negotiating with the ACTU some kind of discounting of the CPI for wage increase purposes. He made a deal which he regarded as very good but which some of us regard as being pretty second-rate whereby, although the inflationary effects of devaluation have already started to flow back into the economy, they will not be reflected in wage increases until a period of six months has elapsed. So the Treasurer made a partial deal but still admitted that costs over and above that which would ordinarily be worked out on the formula would flow back into the economy; in addition, of course, there is that delay of six months. If there is a further devaluation and if overseas investors rate the Australian dollar at less than its current level, this whole cycle will have to be gone through again.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would get the accord mark 3.

—Accord mark 3, as the honourable member for Berowra so correctly says. We would have the same old cycle of devaluation and inflationary pressures on the economy, with imports rising. The Government would have to go back once again to the ACTU, with cap in hand, to ask it: `Please let us discount the inflationary effects of what we have just done?'. That is why the Government is terrified about the possibility of a fall in the dollar. That is why it has to maintain a strict monetary policy to keep up interest rates, which it is doing. It is in a very difficult position as it cannot really say how long that would have to go on.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Australian Financial Review of last Friday there was a report from a respected economist, who stated that no easing of interest rate pressures was foreseeable by the end of the year. Indeed, if we look beyond that, there are no factors we could look at which would give us any hope of a falling off in interest rates. Really, we are between the devil and the deep blue sea. On the one hand we have very high interest rates causing inflationary pressures which will eventually stop investment and will have an effect on the CPI, thus pushing wages up; on the other hand, if we do not keep up those high interest rates we will run the very severe risk of devaluation, with roughly the same consequences on the other side of the equation.

Those are the reasons why this economy, which is claimed by the Treasurer to be the best ever, is fairly shaky when one examines its basis. It all comes back to the mechanism of the Loans Bill 1985 which we hope to pass in the House today and the purpose of which is to make provision for financing Budget deficits. It gives the House the opportunity to reflect a little on the longer term consequences of the policies that have been pursued by this Government and to examine how difficult it would be to fulfil the various promises the Government has made. We in the Opposition wish to draw attention to these things. We certainly do not take any pleasure in the fact that interest rates are at their most historically high level since the Great Depression; we merely warn the Government that unless there is some realistic assessment of the overall economic policy and an end to this self-congratulatory mode into which the Treasurer has moved, all Australians will be suffering in the medium to long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members would be aware that the expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue fund cannot validly exceed revenues available to it and that in order to avoid obtaining approval for additional borrowing from the Australian Loan Council, over a period of years successive governments have introduced legislation in the form of a loan Bill which provides for the financing of the Budget deficit. The Bill before us today is the Loans Bill 1985. This Bill makes provision for the financing of the prospective 1985-86 deficit. I take this opportunity to make some general observations on the fiscal and economic policy which has been pursued by this Government with particular reference to Australia's international indebtedness and the measures which have been taken by the Government to reduce this debt.

SPEECH.PARA: In the broader sense, there is no doubt that Australia is poised to experience its third successive year of strong economic growth, through 1985-86. In doing so, the economy will be building on the progress which has been made over the past two years and in particular on the strong recovery that has been so evident in the private sector. The 1985-86 Budget provides for a deficit of around $4.9 billion. Such a deficit represents 2.1 per cent of gross domestic product and compares with the prospective $9.6 billion deficit that we inherited in 1982-83 when we won government and which would have represented almost 5 per cent of total GDP.

It is worthy of note that, in difficult economic circumstances, the Hawke Government in its three Budgets has reduced the Budget deficit as a proportion of GDP from the prospective 5 per cent that we inherited to 4.3 per cent in 1983-84, 2.7 per cent in 1984-85 and 2.1 per cent for this Budget. Again, it is worthy of note that the current level of 2.1 per cent compares with an average deficit level of 2.9 per cent of GDP through the 10-year period to 1983-84, the majority of which years were of course under the Fraser Government. I repeat that this year's Budget deficit is 2.1 per cent as a percentage of GDP and the average over the last 10 years to 1983-84 has been 2.9 per cent.

It is pleasing that against the background of that marked fall in the Commonwealth sector's borrowing requirements associated with the lower Budget deficits and a reduction in borrowings by Commonwealth authorities, the gross public sector borrowing requirement was reduced by one percentage point in 1984-85 to 7.3 per cent of GDP and by 1.5 percentage points to 5.7 per cent of GDP on a net basis. The lower Commonwealth Budget deficit for 1985-86 and the restraints on borrowings at all levels of government agreed at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council in May 1985 will ensure that there is a further significant reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement as a share of GDP in 1985-86. Real growth in outlays of only 1.3 per cent in this Budget and the Government's commitment to its so named trilogy of budgetary restraint over this term of government will undoubtedly and unquestionably ensure further reductions in 1986-87 and beyond in the Government's public sector borrowing requirements.

Those on the Opposition benches and others in the community who seem to be in many ways ignorant of the realities of government spending programs have over recent times been calling for even larger reductions in levels of government spending. These calls are particularly hypocritical, emanating as they do from an Opposition which left this Government with a projected deficit of $9.6 billion and which during its famed razor gang exercise managed to reduce government spending by only a few hundred million dollars throughout that whole tortuous program. The Opposition's rhetoric simply does not match its performance. The Opposition's performance ought to be compared with this Government's achievements in holding growth in outlays to 1.3 per cent in real terms in this Budget, as well as in May cutting $1.2 billion off the forward estimates of spending programs and reducing the overall Budget deficit from that prospective $9.6 billion which we inherited to the 1985-86 prospective figure of $4.9 billion. We have done all of those things in the space of less than three years. They are notable achievements and compare more than favourably with the performance of the Fraser years.

But those who call for even greater reductions in government outlays need to recognise that almost 60 per cent of all outlays are subject to some form of indexation arrangements. Public debt interest accounts for a further 10 per cent of outlays. It needs also to be said that where the Government has acted to make savings in some of the big ticket outlay areas like social security by introducing the assets test to means test more effectively pension payments, it has been the Opposition and those who are most vociferous in their calls for lower government spending who have been squealing the loudest about our endeavours to make those cuts in areas such as the assets testing of pensions.

I make it quite clear that I am no advocate of excessive or profligate government spending or of the unnecessarily high taxes required to support it. But the debate about lower government spending needs to be kept in a proper and sensible perspective. There are some fundamental facts which need to be known and they need to be properly understood. I will make just three points about that. First, by the standards of most countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, neither taxes nor government expenditure in Australia are high. Australia ranks about sixth lowest of the 23 OECD countries in taxes and government expenditure as a proportion of GDP.

The second point I wish to make concerns the effect on Commonwealth Budget outcomes through the payments of unemployment benefit and income and other taxes forgone as a result of today's unemployment level. If we look at that area and compare it with the level of unemployment in the 1960s, that additional cost and payment in outlays to the Commonwealth is around $5 billion. The extra interest payments required to service the cumulative deficits caused by unemployment over the last 10 years is another $2 billion to $3 billion. (Quorum formed) Before I was interrupted by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) who called a quorum by drawing attention to the state of the House, I was talking about the Budget deficit and the inability of the Opposition to understand some of the realities about the Budget deficit. I was saying that 65 per cent of total government outlays involve some form of indexation and a further 10 per cent are related to debt payment.

If we look at some of the things we have done to make savings in some of the big spending areas like social security where we have introduced the assets test, it is the Opposition and its supporters and those who argue most strongly for reductions in government spending who are the most vociferous in their calls for lower government spending. Members of the Opposition are hypocritical and do not understand the facts. Let us look at what they did a couple of months ago at the Liberal Party council meeting. Here we have a real example of the intelligence of members of the Liberal Party and members of the Opposition. At that council meeting they called for a 4 per cent reduction in government spending. We do not have to be mathematical gurus to know that a 4 per cent reduction in government spending in real terms would require us to cut $9.3 billion off this year's deficit.

The mindless automatons opposite want us to cut $9.4 billion of the Budget deficit. They are not in the House now as they do not like to face the sad reality but I shall explain what it would mean to cut $9.4 billion off the Budget deficit. Firstly, it would mean abolishing any free issue of the Australian flag. That would be a disgrace. Secondly, it would mean cutting back $20 a week on all age, war service disability, invalid and widow's pensions, the supporting parents benefit and the unemployment benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they want.

—That is what they want, as the honourable member for Hotham says. They want to do that. But that is not all because there is only about $1m or $2m in that. We would have to scrap completely the family allowance. What about industry? Honourable members opposite are said to be big supporters of industry. Thirdly, we would have to cancel all payments for industry, the arts and foreign aid. What about cockies' corner? I have gone about half way through the list. To find that $9.4 billion we would also have to abolish the Department of Primary Industry and all the payments that are made through it. I see that two members of cockies' corner are in the chamber. They are supporting the Liberal Party council's call to cut spending by $9.4 billion, which would mean the end of the Department of Primary Industry and all payments made through it.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, of course, we would have to close down the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Atomic Energy Commission. Even after we had done all those things we would have to find another $800m-worth of cuts to do the job. That is what the Liberal Opposition has been calling for. As I have said, we have brought the deficit down from a prospective $9.6 billion, which we faced when we came to government after those disastrous years in office of honourable members opposite, to $4.5 billion. We have reduced it from almost 5 per cent of GDP to 2.1 per cent. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) knows full well that that is a great achievement indeed. Most importantly, we have kept spending growth in real outlays this year to 1.3 per cent in real terms. We have managed to do that while, at the same time, protecting those in the community who need the support of the government. We have done that by protecting them through our welfare programs and, at the same time, we have managed to keep the economy turning over at record growth rates. For the third year in a row we have had a 5 per cent growth in real non-farm GDP. That is an achievement that has not been equalled by any government since World War II. The Hawke Government has achieved it. It has achieved it with a great team of Ministers, a great Cabinet and, above all, a great team of back benchers.

I shall conclude by making a few points about the external debt side of things. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) will also speak on that area. We have heard a lot about the external indebtness of Australia and the buildup of foreign debt. If we look over our performance in the last few years we will see that we have been generating levels of current account deficits which are not sustainable indefinitely. The Government recognises that and it has taken measures to put an end to that and to restore the competitive edge to the Australian economy.

Advertisements have been placed in papers about our foreign debt. Over the last few years the level of Commonwealth debt has doubled from about $6.7 billion to about $12 billion. Honourable members would be aware that most of that is well covered by our foreign exchange holdings. The area that has really exploded in terms of foreign debt is the private sector. That area has increased six-fold since the early 1980s. So in talking of foreign debt we on this side of the House agree that we cannot produce current account deficits indefinitely; they are not sustainable. What we can do is take measures to reduce the amount of indebtedness. Perhaps the most important thing we can do there is get the economy turning over again, keep it going fast, keep the growth rates high and get back to international competitiveness. We have done that through the prices and incomes accord. All the countries in the OECD are talking about the success of the accord. We do not have to big note the accord because people are doing it for us overseas. They are all talking about Australia's prices and incomes policy as the policy that has allowed us to get sustained levels of real economic growth, and sustained levels of job growth while, at the same time, keeping inflation down to a satisfactory level and restoring international competitiveness.

I wish to summarise a few of the points I have made today on this Loans Bill. I have said that in terms of the deficit-that is what this Bill is about; it is a Loans Bill to finance the deficit-we have brought it down from a prospective $9.6 billion to $4.9 billion in 1985-86. In terms of a proportion of GDP-perhaps this is the most remarkable aspect of our performance as a government-we have brought that deficit of $9.6 billion down from 5 per cent to 2.1 per cent. I repeat what I said earlier: Members of the Opposition can whinge and go on all they like. They talk a lot of nonsense. Unfortunately, they did not learn anything when they were in government. If they had half a brain they would be dangerous. We should compare that 2.1 per cent in this Budget with the average for the last 10 years of 2.9 per cent. We have done that.

We had the May economic statement this year. We kept growth in real outlays to 1.3 per cent. We have done that, most importantly, at a time when we have looked after people in need in our community. We have kept the economy going at a great rate. We have improved our international competitiveness. We have generated 487,000 new jobs in less than three years. No government has done that before. I know that I do not have to repeat it but it is important to say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to hear it again. How many?
—We have generated 487,000 new jobs.
—What did the Opposition do when it was in government?

—The honourable member for Melbourne, who is an assiduous member, asked what the Opposition did when it was in government. I make the point that we have created more jobs in two years than the Opposition did in seven years. That is the extent of our performance. It is only a matter of months now before this Government clocks up 500,000 jobs. We will do it in under three years. That is an achievement unparalleled in Australia's economic history.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a 5 per cent growth in non-farm GDP. Industrial disputes are at their lowest levels for 17 years. The rate of increase in real labour unit costs is at its lowest level for more than a decade. So we have got all the fundamentals right and this economy is starting to take off. The economic illiterates opposite simply cannot seem to grasp that. All they are doing is going out into the market-place and overseas and trying to bag this Government and to run down the achievements of this economy and to run down the achievements of industry in generating new jobs. In conclusion, we have had economic idiocy from honourable members opposite in calling for a $9.3 billion reduction in this year's Budget deficit. As I have said before, to do that we would have to cut every single pension payment in Australia by $20 a week. We would have to terminate the family allowance. We would have to cancel every payment to industry, the arts and foreign aid. I do not know where the members of cockies' corner are-there are still one or two of them in the chamber-but we would have to abolish every payment made through the Department of Primary Industry and, of course, we would also have to close down the ABC. —The Government has that type of record in some respects when it comes to interest rates, the difficulty with the balance of payments, and the currency. SPEECH.PARA: It is about time the Australian Labor Party gave up this manifestly phoney, misleading and false charge. It was particularly significantly because, as we all know, the Government then, spuriously, went on to justify abandoning much of its ALP platform on the basis of this figure.

I want to make two points on this: Firstly, the honourable member for Bennelong was quite right in what he said about the deficit `trending higher than the 1982-83 figures', because when the Labor Party won office and assumed actual responsibility for the 1983-84 deficit, it brought in a deficit of about $8 billion, which included additional outlays in respect of its new programs of the order of $2,500m. In short, it got the projected no policy change 1983-84 deficit down from the $9.6 billion to about $5.5 billion; about the sort of deficit which it is likely to realise this year. In government we would have pruned it even further. So in fact the deficit was, as the honourable member for Bennelong said, trending higher than the then $4.4 billion of 1982-83, but only about 25 per cent higher, not higher to the extent of a $9.6 billion deficit as government members accuse.

This second point really takes the candle. When the corresponding forward estimate for 1984-85 was provided to the Hawke Government last March twelve months, the Prime Minister, in a weekend interview, described it as `illusory'; and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when questioned in Parliament the following week, stated that the deficit estimate was based on projections that were so uncertain that they were virtually meaningless, and he refused to release the estimate-

TALK.START.PARA: —Very wise.

—Very wise! Yet he and his colleagues pilloried the former Treasurer and the former Prime Minister for not releasing the previous one which was even less securely based. So then, they refused to release the corresponding estimate for 1984-85 that, as I said they so pilloried the then Treasurer and the Prime Minister for not releasing in respect of 1982-83. It is no wonder that at the time the Australian Financial Review had a leader headed `Deficit duplicity', and I think the Canberra Times had one headed `Prime Minister's image damaged'. It referred to the `deficit duplicity' on the part of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and referred to the whole exercise as `. . . being reduced by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, to one of cynical expediency', which indeed it was and is. The Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State and the honourable member for Bendigo ought to be ashamed for continuing to propagate that lie in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Loans Bill, which is before the House, as previous speakers have said, is to provide for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit for 1985-86, a major thrust being, of course, to provide for the charging of defence spending to the Loan Account to relieve the pressure on the Commonwealth Revenue Fund. While this Bill provides a formal framework in respect of the financing of the deficit, it does not get down to the nitty-gritty of what is actually done to finance the deficit. I suggest that, for example, we take the deficit of $6.7 billion in the year to June last. As I said in a brief comment in the adjournment debate a few weeks ago, an important feature of this year's Budget Papers which has gone unremarked is the Hawke Government's inflationary financing of that deficit. It was a deficit second only to the $8 billion of the year before. But what has not been openly recognised is that the Hawke Government relied on the Reserve Bank of Australia to finance directly or indirectly fully half of that $6.7 billion deficit. That is inflationary finance on a large scale by any standard. Indeed, as I said on that earlier occasion, such a resort by the Hawke Government to central bank financing is tantamount to printing money. It is reminiscent of the Whitlam era, as a reference was made by the shadow Treasurer earlier in his remarks, or perhaps of the activities of Dr Jim Cairns when he was Treasurer.

The circumstances leading to that were: During the first part of the 1984-85 financial year the Government was out to keep the lid on interest rates during the election campaign. In that context there was then the necessity to finance its own profligate spending, the very large increases in spending provided for in the 1984-85 Budget for everything except a few areas such as science and food aid, which apparently it did not rate. There were very big increases. Sport and recreation was up by 60 per cent; the community employment program was up by 40 per cent; spending on housing grants was up by 83 per cent; spending on the Australian Bicentennial Authority was up by 352 per cent; and so on. It was necessary to finance the Government's profligate spending, while at the same time there was strong growth in private sector activity and its demand for finance. In addition, there were complications from the devaluation. In those circumstances the domestic capital markets could not possibly absorb the demands made upon it by the Government.

In responding to a question without notice touching on this matter which I asked some weeks ago, the Treasurer referred to the Government's very proper bond selling program to finance the deficit in the 1983-84 financial year, but he had less to say about 1984-85. It is clear from page 77 of Budget Paper No. 1, Statement No. 2, that initial subscriptions of $7.6 billion to the gross issue of Government bonds during the year were made on the normal scale by the trading banks and, more importantly, by the non-bank sector. Subsequently, a large swag of the holdings were `refinanced'-that is, bought-by the Reserve Bank with the effect of pumping new cash into the system on a large scale. In the outcome the cash-base growth was up 50 per cent on 1983-84 and the increase in money supply, as measured by M3 at $13.4 billion, was nearly twice the growth of the previous year. Whatever the complications of interpretation arising from deregulation in the financial system, that hardly qualified as a `firm monetary policy', as the Treasurer averred the other day that the Government had run `at all stages', and it bodes inflation trouble down the track, albeit policy currently is tight.
Returning to financing the deficit, I refer to the table at page 385 of Budget Paper No. 1, part of which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It can be seen from the table that the crucial non-bank contribution, which represents genuine domestic savings, was very low. With the deficit at $6.7 billion it was only $1.8 billion net. In contrast, in the previous year, 1983-84, the non-bank sector contributed $7.2 billion towards the then deficit of $7.9 billion. In that year the Reserve Bank actually decreased its holding of Governments securities by almost $1 billion. But in the past year the central bank contributed, directly or indirectly, some $3.4 billion-fully half of the deficit funding requirement. As I have said, there was a significant exercise in printing money and inflationary financing.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to the Reserve Bank contributing directly. Included in that direct contribution was the acquisition by the Government from the Reserve Bank, in exchange for bonds, of foreign currency reserves of the order of $1.5 billion. That really represents a straight-out raid on the overseas reserves. The Government avoided the due process of borrowing, as a means of minimising the impact of its overall profligate spending on interest rates and the weak Australian dollar. By proceeding in that way the fundamental problem of the nation living beyond its means was not addressed. The proper process in this regard would have been to make an additional public bond issue designed to tap genuine domestic savings and then to purchase foreign exchange from the foreign exchange market with the proceeds. Of course, that would have put more pressure on the weak Australian dollar, as compared with acquiring the foreign currency by appropriating it from the Reserve Bank stock. It would have put added pressure also on domestic interest rates. But in the outcome, the overall effect would have been less domestic savings available to others in the economy; hence, indirectly, a lesser demand on the balance of payments and a lesser balance of payments deficit, thus a lesser degree of the nation `living beyond its means', and generally a more responsible outcome.

Turning to the 1985-86 Budget deficit, the first point I make is that the deficit has a shop-front label of $4.9 billion. However as has been widely pointed out, the $4.9 billion is achieved after a very large and questionable leap in the payment to the Government's revenue to be made by the Reserve Bank of the order of $800m. That has been based largely on paper gains in the Australian dollar value of foreign exchange reserve sales. As John Stone, the former Treasury Secretary, cogently pointed out, it is tantamount to reducing the deficit on the basis of printing money, this time through the currency depreciation process. After the 1984-85 effort, one might say that the Government is getting the printing of money down to something of an art form.

As for the financing of this year's deficit, it is evident that again the Government is shaping up to play the same tricky games as last year-to adopt a phrase of Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald of 31 August-with the financing of the overseas deficit. The overseas deficit is $3.5 billion, of which the foreign currency component is $2.9 billion. The Government proposes to finance this deficit by `utilising interest credits to reserves', then the main part of $2.2 billion will be financed by the order of $1.1 billion of direct borrowing from overseas and $1.1 billion appropriated from the foreign currency reserve. As I said in talking about last year, that is virtually a grab from those reserves-it is a matter of the direct provision of Government bonds-in effect, rather worthless paper-to the Reserve Bank in return for $1.1 billion of real foreign currency which amounts to a raid on this major asset of the country, namely, the foreign currency reserves. Those reserves total about $13 billion and constitute one offset on the credit side to the worrying gross overseas debt of nearly $70 billion gross, to which the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), referred in his speech.

This procedure of utilising reserves in this way cannot be other than a short term procedure, in that the foreign currency reserves are finite and will not last indefinitely. The proper and responsible process, in the nation's clear situation of living beyond its means, would have been an additional public bond issue tapping genuine domestic savings and then the purchase in the foreign exchange market of foreign currency with the proceeds. By appropriating foreign currency direct and borrowing direct from overseas, first, the Government's new bond selling program is reduced significantly. To that extent upward pressure on domestic interest rates is reduced, which no doubt is good for the Government in the short term. Secondly, by acquiring foreign currency from the Reserve Bank stock rather than from the foreign exchange market, downward pressure on the weak Australian dollar is reduced. Again, that is good for the Government in the short term. But this is the rub: By proceeding in this way, the fundamental national economic disequilibrium we have-the massive deficit in the overseas balance of payments, which threatens the whole economic strategy, the fact that the nation is living beyond its means, which is the country's underlying problem and challenge-is not addressed. The procedure is, as Mr Gittins said, `a neat trick'. Indeed, it is something of a con. The conduct of policy will need to be more sound and responsible if the Government is to guide this country through the very difficult and complex situation ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Loans Bill 1985 I will take up some remarks of both the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). The honourable member for Berowra referred to some claims to fame that Mr Stone may have had. Let me say at the outset that it is not my view that the skids were put under Mr Stone in terms of his position at the Treasury. But if I were Treasurer of this Government, I would have reflected on the contribution that Mr Stone made; for example, 10.4 per cent unemployment, which peaked shortly after we gained office. The honourable member for Berowra qualified in some way this Government's success story in terms of the level of unemployment, from a peak of 10.4 per cent to a current rate of 8.1 per cent and declining rapidly. Honourable members will not need to be reminded that that is a record without equal in terms of the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and, taken in global terms with all the other major economic indices, it is a record unequalled by any post-war Australian government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar articulated at some length the issues relating to the level of Australia's international indebtedness. I was somewhat surprised that he did that. He reflected on the same topic in this House last week, on 8 October, as reported at page 1644 of Hansard, when he said:
Our overseas debt stood at $3,326 for every man, woman and child as at June 1985 compared with $1,571 for every man, woman and child as at June 1983.

I recall the honourable member for Mackellar reiterating those statistics in today's debate, and he also added to them. I shall simply paraphrase what he said, because I do not have a copy of the Hansard this early, of course. The honourable member referred to the public sector debt as representing some $864 for each newborn Australian in 1983, and currently representing about $1,670 for each newborn Australian. Of course, in that analysis he took no account of our foreign reserves; nor did he take account of, qualify or attempt to interpret precisely what those figures mean. This `shock, horror' approach, the crude comparison of 1985 figures with 1983 figures, makes very good tabloid politics, but in no way, shape or form does it indicate any degree of political analysis and, more particularly, it makes very shallow the Opposition's claims to any level of economic expertise.

The history of the Australian economy is, of course, a history of a net borrowing economy. This was the case throughout the whole post-war period-and, I might add, a not inappropriate approach of successive conservative administrations. The issue upon which this House ought to focus is the extent to which borrowings may actually or potentially be such that Australia's ability to service such borrowings may be brought into question. No one disputes that. It is a fundamental of any government's economic approach. It is not the issue as such with which I have concern. I believe that this Government is taking the appropriate policy approaches, and I shall advert to those later. But it is really the way in which this issue has been misrepresented. It has been misrepresented by speaker after speaker on the Opposition benches. Of course, the issue upon which one needs to focus is the trend line level of current account deficits-not, of course, in nominal terms, as is the wont of Opposition members, but as a proportion of gross domestic product-and the extent to which borrowings to service such current account deficits are sustainable over time. The 1985 Budget Papers contained the following statement:

Australia's account current deficit during the 1980s has been at levels which are both well outside the range of previously sustained experience and which are not viable indefinitely. Related to the succession of large current deficit accounts, there has been a rapid growth in Australia's external indebtedness . . .

As I indicated earlier, I agree with this analysis, but it is worth making the following points. The inter-relationship between current account deficits and the requirement upon both public and private enterprise to borrow overseas is clear. It is worth noting that the Fraser Government, with Mr Howard, the honourable member for Bennelong, as Treasurer, embraced current account deficits of around 5 per cent of GDP. This has developed into something of a downward trend line-however, with a significant further decline in prospect. I shall articulate why that decline will continue later in my speech. It is clear that a number of variables have impacted to increase the external deficit significantly in recent years. The honourable member for Berowra will no doubt not dispute those variables. It is largely attributable to the increase in domestic consumption expenditure, as opposed to, or at the expense of, domestic investment expenditure over recent years, and, of course, that has been a fundamental problem with our economy and a number of policy approaches have been adopted by this Government in an attempt to address that very issue.

Another feature of our external debt is the move away from foreign equity in Australian enterprises to the provision of interest-bearing loans to both the public sector and, indeed, the private sector. As indicated by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in another place on 11 September 1985:
. . . a country which takes capital from abroad exposes itself to greater risk if the capital comes in the form of interest bearing loans rather than equity capital.

Of course, that is one of the fundamental issues upon which we ought to be focussing. A potential problem in this regard is that component of our foreign debt used to facilitate corporate takeovers. Throughout these debates, I have not heard any reflection by any Opposition member on the current very high level of corporate takeover activity in our economy. I think that most observers on both sides of the House would agree that these takeovers do not add a great deal to the Australian economy's net wealth or its ability to grow in the future. There are, of course, certain takeovers, rationalisations, and so on, that add to the Australian economy, but, as a general rule of thumb, most honourable members would agree that the very high levels of borrowings required to facilitate the number of corporate takeovers in recent months is not a great contribution to the Australian economy, and it is an issue to which this Government should address its mind.

In any event, regardless of the short term problems that may be associated with the particular pattern of foreign borrowing that we have currently, at least some of these problems should be outweighed in the longer term as we have a greater movement, as reflected in those borrowing ratios, to greater equity in Australian companies. It is a self-evident reality that if we can direct a greater component of our investment into Australian equity in Australian companies, in the longer term there will be benefits to be derived from that.

One of the important components of our foreign debt is, of course, related to movements in the value of the Australian dollar. I think that the component of our total foreign debt directly related to valuation movements in the dollar is some 20 per cent. How that is manifested, for example, is in the practice of Australian borrowers to contract in United States dollars. This was largely a factor, combined with the float, of course, and the subsequent devaluation of the Australian dollar, in the increase in net foreign debt of about $9 billion in 1985-86, compared to the previous year's figure. But of course, that analysis has really been skated over by the Opposition members, who prefer to talk-and I can understand why they do it-in nominal terms, without explaining any of the very many variables that we must address in this quite complex area.

The increase in principal and loan service repayments in such circumstances will, of course, be reversed in the event of an increase in the value of the Australian dollar relative to that of the United States. The honourable member for Berowra will be aware that many economic commentators have been surprised at the continuing high levels of the United States dollar and, in my view at least, there is a reasonable chance that that relationship will change and that the benefits that will follow, by definition, will accrue to Australian borrowers in large part. This scenario is in prospect as the float and devaluation should reduce the current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product.

Contrary to Opposition orthodoxy, the Commonwealth is not a large net foreign debtor. Improvements in gold and foreign currency holdings have left the total public sector a moderate net debtor, whilst the Commonwealth overseas debt substantially equates with its foreign reserve holdings. So enough of the propaganda from the other side which attempts to distort that fundamental reality.

In any event, it is worth concluding on a factual analysis of the components of total external debt of State and Federal governments and statutory authorities, that is, the component of foreign debt guarantee by governments. The article by Mr Leard referred to earlier in debates has been by now substantially devalued in terms of its impact because, quite simply, its approach and figures were wrong. The sum of $26 billion is owed by governments. The figure is not $70 billion as Mr Leard would have it; it is, in a global sense, $68 billion. Mr Leard's figures take no account of foreign reserves. If one takes account of foreign reserves, the net indebtedness, having deducted those items, is some $52 billion. It is up the Opposition benches to explain more fully in its contribution to this area of debate what conclusions it draws from the fact that, of that $68 billion, some $42 billion is owed by the private sector. That is the fundamental.

In terms of the Commonwealth Government's position, our foreign indebtedness is in equilibrim with the other side of the equation-our foreign currency and gold holdings. In terms of total public sector net debt, we could be described only as a moderate overseas debtor. The fundamental issue upon which we ought to concentrate is the $42 billion owed by the private sector and, in particualr, the proportion of that $42 billion that is being used increasingly for corporate takeovers that, by any definition and in most circumstances-I stress the latter point-do not add one whit to the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the main concerns of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations is employment growth and the measure of unemployment in this country. We have been told recently that there has been an improvement in employment and a reduction in unemployment. I put to the Committee today that any improvement in employment is welcome, but that before the Government gets carried away with its enthusiasm and, more importantly, before it becomes utterly convinced that its policies are right for continued employment growth, the present results should be put into perspective. SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, the preliminary figures we have recently seen show that the unemployment rate has dropped from 8.3 per cent to 8.1 per cent. The figures for employment growth reveal that there has been an increase in employment of some 56,000, although it should be noted that only 16,000 of that increase is constituted by full time jobs. The remainder, and overwhelming bulk, of the increase is constituted by part time employment. Although what we have seen is an improvement, it should be understood that this is still far too high a level of unemployment. It should also be understood that if the Government is claiming some sort of comparable improvement on the performance of the previous Government, it is simply not borne out by the figures.

I make it plain at the outset that I think this debate of `we did better than you' and `no you did not, we are doing better than you did' is singularly unproductive and very sterile in an area that deserves far more concern. The point should be made nevertheless, if the Government is relying on the improvement in the figures, that the present unemployment rate is still higher than it was for six of the seven years of the previous Government. During those years the unemployment rate was frequently 5 per cent to 6 per cent until the country was hit by drought and a recession. A further point that puts the situation into some sort of perspective is simply this: We have had an increase, according to recent figures, of 16,000 in full time employment. When one considers that our labour force comprises 7,334,000 people, one sees that that is not a result about which the Government should be shouting from the rooftops.

I make the point again that this comparison is certainly not made for the purpose of scoring any political points but to make the point that, as unemployment is now historically high and seems to be static at an historically high level, now certainly is not the time to pursue blindly existing policies and is not the time, in particular, to pursue policies which can only increase labour costs and, to put it as simply as possible, make it more difficult for employers to employ more people. Paramount amongst those policies is the wages-prices accord which must force into our wage cost structure substantial increases which, at the very least, one should concede is not a policy approach which is conducive to any sort of confidence that there will be substantial increases in employment in this country.

The Government has bargained away, in return for nothing, a 3.8 per cent increase in the present national wage case, at least 2 1/2 per cent in April next year and 3 per cent of the 4 per cent productivity claim which will be before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission next year. If the Government had argued those claims on their merits it may, for all I know, have come to the same conclusion. However, what the Government has done-I venture to say that it will regret it-has been to bargain away those wage cost increases and gain in return little, if anything. In fact, it has lost more than it has gained because it has lost the advantage, which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was crowing about in his Budget Speech, that the Government could have gained by taking policy decisions which were aimed at holding on to the advantages for the industry of this country of the devaluation of the dollar.

Further, there are particular points that should be made about youth unemployment when one looks at it in more detail. The first point to be made is that in September the rate of youth unemployment was 21.6 per cent. It was 21.6 per cent in the previous month also. That is clearly a static situation. If the Government is relying, as I understand that it is continually, on the simplistic point that a drop in the unemployment rate overall shows that its policies are working, presumably it follows that the static youth unemployment rate that we apparently now have must show that its policies are not working for youth unemployment. Secondly, the Government has now admitted that high youth wage costs are a factor in preventing a growth in youth employment. It has admitted it expressly through the mouth of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in the extraordinary television interview which is still the subject of almost daily discussion in this Parliament when the Minister conceded that it was crazy, to use his word, that we should have a situation where youth wage rates were in fact in so many cases adult rates and where there were no youth rates and awards. He conceded that that was crazy and, when asked what he was doing about it, there came that historic reply-nothing. It is time the Government did something about it.

Not only has the Government admitted this expressly through the Minister; it has admitted it by necessary implication by setting up yet another scheme, the trainee scheme, which I readily concede almost certainly has some attraction, but which employs young people by having them paid less than the award wage. If there is a scheme which is designed to have the employer pay the employee less than the award rate, I cannot think of a more necessarily implied admission that the award rate is too high. If the award rate were not too high, presumably more young people would be employed under it. It is for that reason that the Government has directed its attention on this occasion, properly so far as it goes, towards devising a scheme where the employer does not have to bear the burden of the full award wage cost. If what I am saying is correct and has some substance, what the Government should be doing is to follow that admission through into the wider community. What it should be doing is to support those moves that industry and commerce themselves are trying to make to get more realism into youth wages-not only as part of some scheme across the board so that employers will once again find it economical to employ more young people.

There are other things that the Government can do to encourage youth employment. Paramount amongst those is that it should lend its support to those moves for a more liberalised industrial relations system that makes wages more responsive to the individual work place. It must surely be common sense that, if an employer can pay what his employees want, what they are worth and what his business can afford to pay, we will get more employment than is produced by this blind, universal approach which has been accepted in this country. Under our present system it is simply stated that the same wages must be paid, and they must be paid to all employees across the board no matter what an individual business can afford to pay and no matter whether the wages are so high that the employer cannot take on more employees.

There are new industries that the Government should be encouraging, instead of adopting what I suggest is simply a blind adherence to what the Government has been landed with. There is great potential in this country for new industries, particularly in communications. Instead of adopting the approach of leaving things to be carved up between government monopolies and private institutions which hold their licences at the behest of the Government it should encourage those new industries. We could have a wide range of new communications in this country, whether based on new forms of radio and television by new licences being granted or whether based on satellite technology. There is a whole range of them which the Government should be supporting and encouraging and not, as is the case in some circumstances, doing nothing about them or, in other cases, setting its face against them.

There are other matters that the Government can attend to. In regard to the tax package which is presently before the Parliament and which has been announced by the Treasurer, it must surely be apparent to the Government that there are forces contained within that package which cannot militate towards greater employment growth but which, if anything, will militate against employment growth. We heard the way in which the Treasurer today, in that manner that he so often adopts, simply expressed a complete indifference to employees in the restaurant industry and related industries where one would think the Government would look for more support. They are decisions which the Government is making and which are militating against employment growth. They are militating against the expansion of business and commerce and I venture to say that we will not even see over the next few months the growth in employment that we have seen over the last month.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity of this debate this afternoon to refer principally to matters associated with the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. SPEECH.PARA: The situation in regard to employment improvement unfortunately is not as good in Queensland than for other States. The news last Thursday contained somewhat better results for Queensland than for other States. The news last Thursday contained somewhat better results for Queensland, but unfortunately it has not reached the stage when one could say it is anything like good news. Whatever the Queensland Government might like to say, the unemployment rate of almost 9 per cent in that State is anything but good news. The unemployment rate among Queensland youth of 21 per cent is nothing short of tragic, but the figures show that at last, in spite of all the obstruction and confrontation from the State Government, the progressive economic policies of the Hawke Labor Government are beginning to benefit Queensland just as they have led to a dramatic turnaround in other States.

This is not to say that we in Queensland are out of trouble. As a Queenslander, naturally I am quite worried that the obstinate and obstructionist attitude of the Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland could continue to destroy all the gains that the people of that State have made through the initiatives of this Federal Labor Government. Earlier this year we had an example of the arrogance of the Queensland Government when it inflicted immense damage on the struggling Queensland economy by deliberately provoking a power dispute in the hope that it would give it victory in a by-election which was being held at that stage in Rockhampton. Fortunately and understandably the Rockhampton voters refused to be swayed and returned a new Labor member to replace my colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) who had vacated that seat. Hundreds of millions of dollars were lost during that time by businesses battered in a dispute deliberately provoked by the Bjelke-Peterson Government because it thought it might relieve some of the pressure it was under in the Parliament at that time.

Now in another by-election campaign we are set for a repeat of that performance. In an obvious attempt to provoke the trade union movement in Queensland, the Queensland State Cabinet decided last week that it was worth another try and announced that more work in the Queensland power industry would be handed over to outside contractors. The fact that the National Party is again facing a by-election obviously has everything to do with the timing of that decision, as it had with the previous one. Fortunately, I know that the electors in the area concerned on this occasion-the area of the State seat of Redlands comes within my electorate of Bowman-have supported me and the Labor Government in Canberra in the last two Federal elections and they have suffered from the cynical neglect of the Bjelke-Petersen Government over many years. I am sure that they will see the cheap ploy in that Government's announcement about the change in employment arrangements for the power industry. I am sure that they will reject the National Party candidate and see that their representation at State level is by Labor, as it is federally.

This afternoon I wish to refer mainly to the very successful community employment program that was initiated by this Government and is administered by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The problem of unemployment has always been of top priority with the Government, and foremost among the successful schemes for the creation of employment has been the community employment program. In my electorate of Bowman the scheme has been extremely successful. In particular, the Redlands Shire Council and local community groups in the area have used the CEP to create many jobs and to upgrade many existing facilities. More than $2.2m in CEP funds has been committed to help create work for more than 203 local unemployed people. The Budget CEP allocations for this financial year were some $290m on a national level, with some $42.1m going to Queensland. Of this, $10m is available to the Queensland Government for sponsoring projects that it initiates. I am aware that the guidelines for the funding require that 65 per cent of the Commonwealth funds go towards labour costs and I am certain that Queensland abides by those requirements.

My concern is that that State Government, in applying for CEP funds, is utilising them for projects that ordinarily would be within its normal range of departmental activities and that in this way Commonwealth funds are being used by the National Party Queensland Government to balance its own budget. To say that least, such action is contemptible. I have here many examples, which I cannot quote this afternoon because of shortness of time, which clearly show that the Queensland Government has unfairly taken advantage of the community employment program. I also have many examples-again shortness of time does not allow me to list them-of massive amounts of equipment being purchased by the Queensland Government for use on these programs. To my knowledge that equipment then becomes part of the State Government's equipment for use in the future on other jobs. Thus, the Government has been saved the initial expense of purchasing the equipment. It is well to consider that that type of equipment should have some offsetting cost so that some of those funds that are used to purchase it can find their way back into the community employment program, rather than into the coffers of the Queensland Government. From talking to my colleagues I understand that the Queensland Government is not the only State Government that is guilty of this practice, but unfortunately in Queensland it occurs much more often. It is an outright abuse of the CEP scheme and is nothing more than arrogant misuse of Commonwealth Government funds to carry out work which should be undertaken by the State Government from its own Budget appropriations.

This Government must make a decision about the future of the community employment program after 30 June 1986. I believe, and I put this to the Minister, that the guidelines should be changed. I strongly urge that direct funding to State governments be discontinued when those guidelines are revised. Such discontinuation would prevent any further misuse of funds, and if State governments have a genuine interest in assisting the unemployed and creating job opportunities for them, they will have ample opportunity to undertake that responsibility directly through their own State Budgets. I believe that funds that come from the CEP should be totally allocated to local government and community organisations, which often lack the large funds necessary to carry out those sorts of programs. Certainly they would be able to initiate projects of more direct and general benefit to local communities. It is certainly my wish that the CEP should continue as it provides an important step back into the work force for many long term unemployed. Under CEP these people are given an opportunity to regain their confidence, learn new skills, and have a source of current work experience and perhaps even a recent employment reference, both of which are a definite advantage when applying for jobs. The new scheme the Government has in mind for 16 and 17-year-olds will not become effective for some time. In the meantime many who missed out on employment opportunities when they left school are being and will continue to be assisted by the CEP. Until the new scheme becomes fully implemented they will continue to receive opportunities through the CEP, and in the past it has certainly been of great advantage to the youth in my area.
