SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the appropriation for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, I wish to follow the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) and highlight the disturbing trend in youth unemployment. No matter how much gloss the Government attempts to paint over the situation of youth unemployment, the simple, cold, hard facts are that the problem is not getting better and, in some aspects to which I will address myself later, such as rural unemployed youth, it is worsening. The figures tell a very sad tale. For males aged between 15 and 19 the unemployment rate for September was 20.4 per cent; for females aged between 15 and 19 it was slightly higher at 23.2 per cent. This means that the combined unemployment rate for 15 to 19-year-olds was 21.6 per cent. This is to be compared with the unemployment rate of 6.8 per cent for those aged over 20. This gives us an overall unemployment rate for all persons in the work force of 8.1 per cent. Sadly, I do not believe that this Government is addressing the problems of youth unemployment with the urgency that is required. The priority program upon which the Government has solely relied is in an early stage and my great fear is that, firstly, it will fail to pick up a great many unemployed youth, and secondly, it will fail to pick many of the rural unemployed youth.

SPEECH.PARA: Few Australians would deny that unemployment and inflation have been the scourge of both metropolitan and rural life of the past 15 years. As we all know, the causes are manifold and the solutions apparently are few. The resources to identify and then perhaps alleviate unemployment are regarded generally as being more abundant in city and regional centres. Youths, always the main sufferers in an economic downturn, have added difficulties and problems with unemployment when they are beyond the limelight of the Press and, in some cases, beyond even their own political representatives. I believe that there are some very serious blank spots in research in this area and for that reason I decided to investigate the issue. Some weeks ago I forwarded to 250 postmasters and postmistresses throughout all States of Australia a questionnaire seeking their views on youth unemployment because they are at the hub of a community, at the coal face, if you like. The towns I chose were in isolated, relatively remote parts of Australia and had populations of between 500 and 1,000. I received a total of 100 replies, and I point out that I received those replies within 48 hours. Regrettably, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) felt moved to veto or prevent any other replies. An instruction was sent out from Australia Post to the postmasters and postmistresses telling them not to answer the questions. The Minister forwarded me his own condemnation. He said he believed the figures and the research obtained would be used in a political sense and that this would be, in some way, politicising public servants. I reject that. I have distributed the results of that survey to all members of parliament.

What has to be remembered is that in the country, particularly in the relatively isolated rural areas, youth unemployment exists often to a greater degree than in the cities and larger towns. Employment opportunities are smaller and narrower, with the numbers, size and diversity of industries confined by the limitations necessarily imposed by rural conditions. Furthermore, educational and training facilities are restricted, travel and transport services are reduced and communications are hampered by these places remote locations. As a consequence, the motivation to combat the frequently depressing and debilitating effects of medium to long term unemployment is reduced or lost. Little has been done to measure the extent and effects of youth unemployment in rural Australia.

The results of the survey that I undertook were compiled from evidence supplied by front line observers in some of Australia's smaller centres. It sets out, admittedly in only a smallway, to shed some light on one of our more pressing social problems. The survey was based on a set of six questions which sought the respondents' views on the extent of unemployment in their areas, the activities of the unemployed, local support for the unemployed and prospects for improvement. Furthermore, respondents were asked whether any significant support for unemployed females should be undertaken and, finally, what suggestions they could make which they believed would stimulate youth unemployment.

The replies to the survey were certainly not exhaustive but the findings represented a pretty fair reflection of opinion on the extent of youth unemployment, its effects and its potential solutions. What can be said is that nearly 60 per cent of the respondents indicated that the problem was worsening in their areas, with 70 per cent claiming little hope for improvement. Prominent among suggestions offered as solutions by survey respondents included: First, more local government supervised youth employment programs; secondly, greater support for industry in rural areas; and thirdly, the initiation of local government and community projects to be paid for with the unemployment benefit, meaning that unemployed youth must undertake some government or community work to receive the unemployment benefit.

I call upon the Government to place greater emphasis on local government as a means for dealing with unemployed youth, particularly in remote areas. I also call upon the Government, as a matter of urgent importance, to undertake a national survey into rural youth unemployment. I realise that the statistics gathered by the Commonwealth Employment Service are readily available, but they do not tell us anything like we need to know if we are to identify the sources of unemployment and possible solutions to the problem.

The concept of a national survey arose out of a youth unemployment conference that I held two or three months ago in my electorate in the city of Sale. That conference was chaired by Professor Dame Leonie Kramer. More than 130 community representatives from Gippsland alone attended the conference, which again highlights the concern with which citizens in rural and remote areas of Australia view youth unemployment.

I thank those good postmasters and postmistresses who replied to the survey. I believe that the full complement of 250 would have done so but for the intervention of the Minister for Communications. Their concise descriptions and open analysis of local conditions are a credit to them and their organisation and, I believe, have contributed greatly to the successful formulation of the survey report which I have circulated. However, I stress it is only a pilot study and so much more needs to be done.

One of the most interesting aspects of replies to the survey related to the activities of the unemployed. Respondents to the survey indicated an overall tone of objectivity and understanding in their responses. However, it would not be unfair to suggest that a number of respondents allowed a measure of disapproval to enter their replies. The Government is charged with a special responsibility, and that is to ensure that bias against or disillusionment with the youth of our country is not allowed to foster to any greater extent than is apparent at present. The only way of dealing with this prejudice is to get our young people, particularly our young rural unemployed, back to work. With regard to Priority One: Young Australia, with its almost total reliance on traineeships or work study programs, I urge that local government be accorded many of those traineeships because it is in the best position both to identify and to deal with youth unemployment in rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate today that the two departments of Employment and Industrial Relations and Industry, Technology and Commerce, are linked together in this debate on the Budget-Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86-because it is this Government that actually started those two departments working in unity. In that context, it is appropriate to consider the unemployed and the training of the work force of our community. Investment programs, technology, research and development should all be very much involved with industrial relations and industry and commerce policy making. In recent times, we have seen the result of that policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I come to the main part of my discussion, I wish to express my very deep regret that when the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), was the Minister for Communications, with responsibilities for all postmasters and postmistresses and all the activities of Australia Post throughout Australia, he did not go to the trouble to do the kinds of things that the Opposition is now talking about. In fact, it is rather unfortunate that the Opposition's sudden awareness of youth unemployment, not just in rural Australia but in the whole of Australia, has been so late in coming. Certainly, the previous Government carries a great responsibility for what is perpetrated on the community that it represented. If the current Leader of the National Party had done the homework he should have done when he was the Minister perhaps we as a government would not be facing the problems we are facing now.

This is the first Budget in which the technology section has come under one Minister in the portfolio of Industry, Technology and Commerce. That shift, of the technology section has been reflected in the expenditures in the Budget Papers and therefore in the Appropriation Bill. The benefits of that change are now becoming visible with the transfer of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and various other research and technology components to that portfolio.

The fact is that under the current Government we have seen massive changes in the last 2 1/2 years in the Australian Industry Development Corporation and in the development of the management investment corporations. Since 1 July, we have had a tax write-off of 150 per cent for research and development expenditure. These changes are very much part of industry policy. They are the precursors of our industrial revival, the industrial rejuvenation, that this country has so long waited for.

Looking back at industry employment figures in Australia in recent years, in 1982-83 there was a decline in the metals products section of manufacturing of some 10 per cent. In the following year it declined by another 6 per cent. The fact is that the policies of the previous Government were sending our manufacturing sectors into absolute and total decline. We came to government in March 1983 and industries were on their knees. I pay particular reference to the steel industry. In my area alone, employment dropped from 11,250 in 1981 to just on 6,000 by 1983; in other words almost half of the employees of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd steelworks in Newcastle had been retrenched, made redundant or disemployed, whatever term one likes to use.

When we came to government Australia had had some 30 years or more of a policy import replacement and the psychology and attitudes which go with that. That particular policy, which was a legacy of the Menzies-McEwen era, was that, if a good was manufactured in Australia, we did not need to import it; tariffs were imposed on those imports to protect the Australian industry. As a pure theory from the conservatives and economic managers of whom the country thought so highly in those days, it seemed okay; but what it created was a situation in which, firstly, the vast majority of our manufacturing industries involved manufacturing under licence with the marketing rights for Australia only, which meant that there could be no export of most of those goods. In effect, we created a high cost, low volume manufacturing sector in Australia. The second result was that we created an attitude, a psychology of: `It does not matter how much it costs or how well we make it; if we become uncompetitive, we will just increase the tariffs'. It was that mentality that made our industries in Australia perform so poorly in world terms.

With the introduction in mid-1983 of the steel industry plan, for the first time we saw a great change in the direction of industry policy. Historically in Australia we had had only two models of industry. One model was that of arm's length, which meant that the Government knew nothing about it and it was none of the government's business. The second model was one of nationalisation, which meant that the government owned the industry. The arm's length policy had been significantly deficient, and the steel plan showed that. What the Fraser Government said in 1982, when the steel industry collapsed, was: `We do not know what it is about'. In fact, for the benefit of honourable members, I mention that, when we convened a public meeting in Newcastle to try to come to terms with the problem, the then Federal Government was not prepared to send any Minister to talk to us about it. In fact, what the Prime Minister of the day did was to refer the matter to the Industries Assistance Commission because it might know something about it. The arm's length policy meant that the government knew nothing, could do nothing and therefore in some way could not be held responsible. Of course, under conservative governments we had nationalised industries being part of government policy. The famous example was the Australian National Line, where the public industry aim was to serve Country Party policy and not the people of Australia.

With the introduction of the Steel Industry Authority we saw a great change. For the first time we had the establishment of a neutral interface between the industry and government in the form of the Steel Industry Authority, the Authority being made up of government, employees and the employer. That Authority has been seen to be extremely effective. It allows government to be informed by the Authority, which monitors not only Australian industry but also world industry. In other words, somebody in Australia is taking responsibility for measuring, monitoring and looking ahead for the steel industry. The results of that are now becoming very clear. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is undertaking a massive investment program which will be of enormous benefit to the Australian steel industry. We find our industry is becoming competitive and will be able to survive in the future. It takes not just investment by BHP but also investment by government in monitoring and leading and setting the policy climate to allow that industry to recover and to work.

The Steel Industry Authority was a precursor to the tripartite industry policy structure. We have now seen its successors in the authomotive industry and the shipbuilding industry. In both cases a similar neutral interface has been established between government, industry and the employees. We are now seeing the recovery in the automotive industry. I can assure honourable members that the figures for the shipbuilding industry are also extremely encouraging. If one looks at the expenditures in some of these areas by this Government, the shift will be seen. For the shipbuilding industry, there has been an increase of almost $20m over the last two years. In the current Budget $35m is being spent on design and research for the automotive industry; in other words, there is a positive contribution by government towards that industry.

I make the point that this Government has not said to industry: `It is all your problem. The onus is on you'. We have been saying that the government has a positive role to play. We will play our part if industry plays its part. The unions are required to play their part in terms of industrial arrangements, demarcation disputes and dispute settling procedures. In the last couple of years we have seen the greatest reduction in and the lowest level of industrial disputation for some 20 years.

In the computer bounty legislation that we introduced in 1984 we saw yet another shift and extension of government policy. It involved the provision of bounty on sales overseas. What we had had in Australia was a totally inward looking industry policy in which any form of support was available only for the domestic market. That happened with shipbuilding and computer manufacturing. With computer manufacturing we established a policy that makes a bounty available for the value added components in Australia for sales outside Australia. In other words, we saw it as a production bounty. It did not matter whether it was sold in Australia or overseas; the benefit was still the same. For the first time we encouraged our industries to be outward looking, to look beyond the small Australian market and the fairly narrow Australian capacity. The same philosophy was applied to shipbuilding. In Newcastle alone in the last eight months two companies have received enormous benefit with sales to New Zealand as a result of that export bounty on shipbuilding.

What we have tried to do as a government is to restructure, rethink and redirect Australian industry. It is a long, slow and hard process. But to date, if one looks at the steel automotive, computer and shipbuilding industries, one sees the results emerging and in terms of new technology as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to remark briefly on the nature of the debate. We are in fact debating in Committee the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 as it relates to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Committee stage of this Bill takes the place of what was an experiment during the Fraser years with House of Representatives Estimates committees, which were abandoned by that Government. I hope that this Government will take on board the nature of the very debate that we are having today. There is a very unsatisfactory element about it in that people from both sides of the House make speeches giving their points of view, but the net result is not discussion around the table as was the case in the old days of the House of Representatives Estimates committees. I believe that this House is at a significant disadvantage compared with the other House, the Senate, which has Estimates committees. We could re-institute Estimates committees to the great advantage of this chamber and its members. It would be particularly advantageous in looking at the detailed statements that we have before us.

SPEECH.PARA: We have explanatory notes on the estimates of expenditure and receipts from both departments. It is interesting to look at them because they are in great contrast with each other. Although much work has been put into them, the explanatory notes of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce are a morass of figures, with little explanation except in the preface. In contrast, those of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations state in the introduction that an important element of the Government's budgetary and financial management reforms has been the study of the possible introduction of program budgeting. These notes are a start along that track for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I found this very useful in the notes of that Department when compared with those of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.

I recommend to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the public servants present today a switch to the program budgeting type of estimates preparation along the lines of the estimates of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. As is stated, it improves the information available for public and parliamentary scrutiny and for upgrading program management by departments. It makes it easier for all of us, especially members of the House, because, when debating appropriation Bills, we are talking about spending taxpayers' money. In the past there has been a presumption in this country that the more money that is spent, the greater is the job being done. That is a myth that needs to be debunked. We must get to the end of that road. In fact, the more money that is spent the more taxpayers' money is used, and we really have to reduce taxation in this country. The only real way of doing that, rather than by shuffling the deck chairs on the Titanic, which I think this tax package does-perhaps it will make it hit another iceberg-is by cutting government expenditure, and that is what this debate ought to be about.

This Committee and, I believe, Estimates committees would provide the venue for honourable members on both sides of the House to look at where the taxpayer is getting value for money. Members of parliament can do that by looking through detailed programs and the explanations of them and they can quiz the departments. In the old Estimates committees the Ministers had officials with them. In this way we can see how the taxpayers are getting value for their dollar. This would facilitate the debate on the cutting of government expenditure, and it is a debate that needs to take place. The debate ought to be on how government can be made more efficient and responsive to community needs and it ought to be about reducing the size of government. In fact, I think that is the great structural challenge.

The more all of us on both sides of the chamber talk about the pros and cons of tax packages and the more we talk about changing the taxation system-I do not propose to debate the tax package today-the more we fall into the self-fulfilling prophecy that we will have higher taxation. We need to switch the debate and talk about how we can cut the size of government. If we cut the size of government and have a more efficient and leaner government we will have lower taxation. I think the move towards program budgeting that we see in the employment estimates before us, combined with changes to the committee structure of this place, are ways in which governments can reduce expenditure.

I turn now to the industry and technology appropriation in the Budget. I think the Budget itself should be about setting the scene and the climate for the growth of the small business sector. I think the small business sector is the key to the future of this country. It is the key to jobs, employment and profits. The nature of the corporate sector is changing. At present, large corporations are rationalising and cutting costs. They are getting rid of departments and merging with other companies because inflation and costs have affected them dramatically. Large companies are getting rid of advertising and engineering departments and that is providing opportunities for small firms outside to take that work. But the large corporate sector will not be a net generator of jobs in the future. Therefore, we have to look at the small and medium-sized business sector. The job of any government ought to be to create the climate, the framework and the environment in which the small business sector can grow, in which people can be encouraged to invest and commit capital to small business and, having committed that capital, to have profits in that business. Through profits we have jobs. If we do not have profitable companies and a profitable private sector the bottom line is that we do not have employment. That is what the Budget ought to be about.

We should ask ourselves whether this Budget is good for small business and, whether it sets in place the framework and creates an environment for small business to invest, grow and prosper. It does not. If we look at the whole series of actions of this Government, of which this Budget is a central element and the tax package is another element, we will see that the tax-wages deal done with the Australian Council of Trade Unions for deferred discounting until April savegely hits the corporate sector. There is no incentive left. Who would want to invest in a new small business today? Governments, in framing Budgets and all policy in the industry, technology and commerce area, have to ask themselves: Will this help the growth of the business sector, particularly the growth of the small business sector? The answer, clearly, in relation to the Budget is no, as it is in relation to the tax package.

As I have mentioned, government ought to be creating the environment and the climate for the small business sector to grow. That is where the industrial relations appropriations are interesting. The program is there. As I have said, the appropriations are well set out but they indicate that a large amount of revenue in this country today is being put aside by government for training and re-training, trade training, vocational training, industry training, job creation and employment assistance, employer incentives, community employment, mobility assistance, community youth support schemes, community support-our youth unemployment is one of the highest, if not the highest, in the Western world-and other assistance. In a large part of these estimates the Government programs how we can spend money to help people to get jobs and train people for jobs. I am not knocking people who are being trained for jobs but I wonder how much better it would be if the money was spent not on training but in creating a climate and an environment for small firms to employ those people through a deregulated, flexible wages system-a change to the industrial relations system in this country which is sorely needed.

When I was shadow Minister for small business I met many young people who wanted jobs and many employers who said to me: `The award wage is $300 a week but I am prepared to take on a young person to work in this business for $150 a week. There are young people who want those jobs at $150 a week'. How much more profitable would it be and how much expenditure would it save if the employer could make an arrangement for that employee to work in that business? It would save all the training programs because this would be on-the-job work experience and the bureaucracy would not have to administer the training programs. In fact, we would be a saving government expenditure.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few things about the points raised by honourable members in this debate, and I thank them for their contributions to the debate. It is inevitable in a discussion on employment that people will say that it is not good enough; that we should have more employment and less unemployment. However, it should be said that Australia's record of employment growth in the past couple of years has been exceptional by national and international standards. Certainly this Government has nothing to be ashamed of in terms of its employment performance in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a tremendous turnaround from the situation we inherited when we came to office. This Government inherited 10.2 per cent unemployment and an economy that was going downhill fast. In the 12 months prior to this Government coming to office there was an absolute loss in employment of 180,000 jobs and unemployment increased by a quarter of a million. That situation has been turned around so dramatically that Australia now has the fastest growing economy in the Western world. We are creating employment faster than any other country in the industrialised Western world. We are now performing so well that other countries are looking to Australia, talking about the Australian model and wondering about the secret of our success. It is simple. The secret of our success has been that we have applied the policies we said we would when we were in opposition. Those policies are based on the absolute priority and essentiality of providing employment. They have been achieved by pursuing an expansionary budgetary policy and a wages policy which has been concerned to ensure that we did not have a blow-out of wages and inflation as a result of that expansionary budgetary policy, as has so often been the case in the past.

If one looks at the record of this Government, one must say that the employment growth has been extraordinary-far beyond the expectations of most people. There has been an increase in employment of 487,000 since April 1983, compared with 340,000 in the seven years of the previous Government. I stress that approximately 70 per cent of those jobs have been full time jobs. Indeed, in the last financial year 75 per cent of the job growth has been in full time jobs. Importantly, in view of the fact that it is sometimes raised by honourable members opposite, most of this job growth has been in the private sector. It is simply not true, as is sometimes alleged, that most of the job growth is occurring through Government subsidies or Government expenditures. We are creating most of the jobs in the private sector. Seventy per cent of jobs created have been in the private sector. In the last two years, 75 per cent of jobs created have been in the private sector, and in the last 12 months, 86 per cent of growth in employment has been in the private sector. As the recovery goes on, a higher and higher proportion of the jobs are being created in the private sector. That is because with the strengthening of the economy there is a greater capacity for employers to take on labour.

The basic conditions are there for increased employment. There has been a considerable reduction in the real level of unit labour costs. Profitability in industry has increased, so it is now more profitable to be in business and therefore there is more incentive to take on employees. Our international competitiveness has increased considerably and there is a higher level of demand. For all those reasons there is understandably a strong growth in employment. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has predicted that employment growth in Australia will be 2.75 per cent for the calendar year 1985, as against 1.25 per cent for the whole of the OECD countries. For 1986 it expects a 2 per cent growth for Australia, compared with one per cent for the whole of the OECD countries.

Employment in Australia is expected to increase at double or more than double the rate of growth of the rest of the industrialised world. It is not credible for people to stand up, in those circumstances, and say that we are not doing a good enough job; that unemployment is too high. We do not deny that it is too high at 8 per cent, but it is certainly a lot better than 10 per cent plus, as it was when we came into office. If we can continue these policies, as we strongly expect we will, and they continue to be successful, we will certainly see further reductions in the level of unemployment at a time when many countries are finding it impossible to reduce unemployment and unemployment levels are continuing to increase.

The Opposition spokesman on industrial relations has said in this debate that the Government has bargained away for nothing the prospects of capitalising on the devaluation and so keeping economic growth going. Clearly, that is not what the OECD expects, because it is forecasting strong economic growth for Australia and strong employment growth. So, the Opposition is out of kilter with the OECD forecasters but it is also out of step with reality, because the reality is that we have achieved an arrangement with the ACTU in which we have very much established the basis for capitalising on that devaluation. We have an agreed 2 per cent discount off the national wage case in April of next year and that, in association with the postponement and the very prolonged implementation of any productivity case outcome, will mean that we are able to fully accommodate, through our wages policy, the impact of inflation, and to ensure that the inflationary impact from devaluation does not get built into our system and that it is able to be removed from the system and that by 1987-88 we shall be back to 5 per cent inflation. So in those circumstances there is, again, no reason to believe that we cannot maintain strong economic and employment growth. Of course, we already have the unemployment rate down to 8.1 per cent-the lowest rate for three years-and with the forecast increases in employment which we expect and which the OECD expects, that rate will continue to decline, even though from time to time there will probably be some momentary increase in it through variations in the work force participation rate.

In this debate there has also been some discussion about the youth labour market and the fact that we still have a high level of youth unemployment. Certainly we have a high level of youth unemployment. At 21.6 per cent for teenagers that rate is disturbingly high; but it is much less than the 28 per cent that it was when we came to office. Although it has dropped considerably, we would be the first to agree that it needs to be reduced to much lower levels before anyone could feel reasonably satisfied. However, let me say firstly that, quite clearly, the policies that we have been pursuing have enabled us to have a considerable expansion of youth employment. For a very long time in this country, and certainly through the period of the previous Government, we have been experiencing reducing youth employment. Indeed, it goes back into the late 1960s that the downturn in employment for youth began, and it continued right up until the last couple of years. During the seven-year period of the previous Government, teenage employment declined by 31,000. Since we have been in office, we have seen teenage employment increase by 38,000. That is a 6 per cent increase over the past two years. It is a substantial turnaround from the trend that we inherited. Looking at youth on a wider scale-that is, those aged 15 to 24-it can be seen that we have had growth in employment for youth of 83,000 in the last two years. So there has been a considerable growth of youth employment. It is quite misleading to suggest that we are unable to create jobs for young people. We have done so. But given the enormity of the problem that we inherited, we still have that unemployment rate at a level which is far too high.

The Government is not simply relying on continued economic growth and associated employment growth to bring down those youth unemployment levels. We have introduced, in particular, the traineeship scheme to try to ensure that we have a much more rapid impact, particularly at the level of teenagers and young teenagers, who are people who often have extremely severe problems in the employment area when they leave school before year 12 and go into the work force with no vocational or educational skills and, therefore, are not particularly attractive to employers, and they suffer from periodic bouts of unemployment, and may spend the rest of their lives going through bad employment performance unless something is done to assist them.

We believe that it is very important-and the various reports that we have commissioned have said that it is important-to give young people more vocational skills. If they are leaving school early and not going into some form of structured training or on to some other form of professional qualifications they need to have a form of structured training. That is what the system of traineeships is designed for-to provide a system of structured training for the vast bulk of school leavers who leave school before year 12, and there are about 100,000 of them every year who do not go on to be an apprentice or do not go on to some other form of education but go into the labour market and suffer, in many cases, severe unemployment problems.

It has been said by the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs and by the OECD review of youth policy that a major step in correcting that is to give young people vocational skills. The traineeship scheme which we are now introducing will do a great deal to assist in providing those skills to young people. It will be a revolution, a very substantial transformation in the whole process of young people moving from school to work. We have already announced the first traineeships, which are with the Ansett company. We expect to announce many thousands more in the course of this year and, in the course of the next few years, to take the annual level of traineeships up to some 75,000.

It has been said in this debate by the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations that the fact that the wage being set for trainees was less than the full award rate indicated that the Government acknowledged that youth wages were too high. That is an absolute misconception or deception, depending on which way one interprets the motives of the person who said it. The reality of the situation is that the trainee wage we are setting is certainly less than the award rate, because in most cases the wage reflects that the fact that there is less than a full week's work being performed by the trainee; that is, the trainee, over the course of the year, will be on the job for only 75 per cent of the time, since the traineeship consists of employment on the job, training on the job and training off the job, and for the time off the job there will be no payment. That means that the wage set must take account of that fact and, therefore, one starts off at 75 per cent of the award rate. There can be also, under the criteria that we have established, a further reduction to account for the fact that there is considerably enhanced training on the job by the employer. That means additional cost to the employer and loss of productivity to the employer. Therefore, it is not unreasonable to say that in that situation, in which there is a considerably increased amount of training on the job as compared with what previously existed before traineeships were introduced, there should be some further reduction in the wage to take account of that.

That is quite a different situation from saying that because one has less than the full award rate applying to traineeships we are acknowledging that youth wages across the board are too high and should all be reduced, because we are talking about a separate situation-a training situation, not an employment situation. Traineeships are about training, and training on and off the job. The wage which is set for that reflects the special circumstances of the fact that that training is occurring in a structured way and it is not normal productive employment in the sense that young people are hired at present without the structured traineeships being in existence.

So, it is misleading and totally incorrect for the Opposition to claim that the introduction of trainee wages at less than full award rate indicates an acceptance on our part that junior wages across the board are too high. We remain very confident that the policies that we have been pursuing will continue to produce strong employment growth in this country. They are a tremendous turnaround from what we inherited. I am sure that the people of Australia recognise that, and I am sure that all honourable members, including those on the Opposition benches, recognise in their hearts that what has happened on the employment front has been remarkable. I only wish the Opposition members could have been anywhere near as good when they were in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the meagre 10 minutes allotted to each speaker I wish to address two matters: First, the Australian Constitutional Convention and constitutional change and, secondly, the question of access to the courts and legal aid. On page 30 of the explanatory notes for the estimates of the Attorney-General's Department an amount of $200,000 is set aside for 1985-86. It appears that provision has been made for the holding of a plenary session of the Convention scheduled for the second half of 1985. Presumably, that is the purpose of the item. We are aware from what we have read in the Press that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has some proposals for what has been quoted to be a `radically revised Constitution'. I think that quotation appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 October.

SPEECH.PARA: One question I ask the Attorney-General is: What effect will his constitutional proposals-that is, effectively to have a constitutional commission-have on the Constitutional Convention? The Attorney will recall that at the last meeting of the Constitutional Convention a motion was moved by Mr Fordham, the Deputy Premier of Victoria, and seconded by Mr Neil Brown which dealt with the future of the Australian Constitutional Convention and, amongst other things, said that an Australian Constitutional Convention should be constituted and provision made for the ongoing work of that Convention. The Council is set down to continue its work and the question is: In view of the announcement that has been made in relation to the Attorney-General's proposal to have a constitutional commission, what will be the role of the Convention? Will the Convention have any role at all? Will the Council have any role at all or is it to be rolled up? I would be glad if the Attorney would tell us what the role is to be and, if it is to have a role, how it is going to work with the commission which he proposes.

As for the proposed commission, I should be glad if the Attorney would tell us how far its work has been advanced and what its composition is to be. It has been reported that persons who are being considered for the commission include the author, Mr Thomas Keneally, the media personality, Mr Ray Martin, and the singer Mr Peter Garrett. I do not question the accomplishments of these people in their own fields. However, I ask: What is their individual or collective suitability or usefulness for the purposes of a commission whose job it is, as I understand it, to examine the Constitution? What instructions does the Attorney-General propose to give this commission about the constitutional changes he has in mind? What constitutional changes does he have in mind? Does he propose major shifts of power between the States and the Federal Government? Does he propose that there should be a major grab or grant of power by or to the Federal Government? When he looks to his commission, how does he see it working? People can be extremely skilled in their own areas, but when they are asked to look at questions of constitutional reform it is a job like any other and it is a job that requires skills. It is an intricate and difficult task which requires that one understand the Constitution-that one understands something about the history of the Constitution, how it is interpreted and how laws are interpreted-so that one has an understanding of what one is to put in its place.

On 1 October the Sydney Morning Herald reported the Attorney-General as saying-I do not know whether it is correct-that he wants to have a brand-new document. In an earlier edition of the Sydney Morning Herald, on 4 March 1985, he was reported as making some general comments about what he wants to see a rewritten Constitution covering. One of the comments that is either made of him or attributed to him-I do not for a moment say that the quotation is necessarily a correct quotation-concerns wage rates and ways to control inflation. Does that mean that power is to be transferred to the Commonwealth for that purpose?

The Attorney-General is reported as saying or has attributed to him the view that section 92 of the Constitution causes problems when States try to establish regulations to control marketing. For many years section 92 has been a barrier against State control or marketing exercises and enterprises and a barrier that has prevented the Commonwealth from controlling interstate trade. Section 92 was put into our Constitution to prevent controls over interstate trade so that we should be one country, and I understand from the Attorney's remarks that he is concerned that we should be one country. In that event, what does he intend to do about section 92? Does he intend to get rid of it? Does he intend to qualify it? Does he believe that it should apply to the Commonwealth? Does he believe that States should have the power to establish regulations to control marketing within the various States? If that is what he intends, he is taking us back to the situation that existed before Federation. In short, therefore, what are the Attorney-General's intentions? What are the areas within the Constitution that he believes require change? What are the directions that he wants to see constitutional change take? What are the specific proposals that he would have Australians make for 1988?

If we are to have a constitutional commission, if we are to have a Constitutional Convention, the Attorney-General must, as the Attorney-General of this country, tell us clearly what he expects that commission or Convention to achieve. If we do not have leadership by him or clear directions from him, we do not understand where we are meant to be going and, more than that, the Australian people as a whole are not being told where he wants to go.

If we are to have a brand-new Constitution-I must say that I see no reason at all for a brand-new Constitution without for a moment saying that the present Constitution is perfect-I should like the Attorney to tell us what that brand-new Constitution is to involve.

I turn to the second subject I want to address-legal aid and access to the courts. I am sure that the Attorney-General would agree with me when I say that access to the courts is fundamental. We can have the best of legal systems and reform the laws as best we can, but if ordinary Australians do not have access to the courts because the costs deny them the price of entry, the system fails. I see on page 78 of the explanatory notes for the appropriations of the Attorney-General's Department that there is to be a cut of some $5m. I am not quite sure how that is made up or the purposes for it. It may well be that this amount has been taken up in some other way. However, I should be glad if the Attorney would explain that item to me. In saying that, I realise that overall there is to be a major increase in the funding for legal aid. At the same time, I would like the Attorney-General to express a view as to the role and utility of the private profession and to contrast it in his opinion with the role of salaried counsel within the legal aid organisations. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to spend the few moments available to me looking at what I perceive to be some of the problems that exist in relation to the Family Court of Australia. I hope to do so in a relatively non-partisan fashion. If I can avoid doing so I do not want to go into the moral and philosophical questions which underlie marriage and the dismantling of marriage in our society. Obviously one would need far more than 10 minutes to do such a thing. I do not want to discuss those well canvassed issues of the jurisdictional problems arising under our Constitution; nor do I want to deal with substantial legal matters such as matrimonial property, which has recently been the subject of a report, and various other substantive legal points. Rather, accepting the philosophy behind the existing Act, I want to deal with the question of how it can be developed to better meet the needs of those involved as efficiently as possible and at a minimum cost to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the Family Law Act is that it was a very pioneering piece of legislation which was passed in 1974 and came into effect in 1976. The climate in which it came into existence was one of a great deal of fear and concern. The doctrine of fault was being overturned and a no fault system, at least in relation to the primary question of the divorce itself, was being instituted. The traditional adversary process in the Supreme Court had been the order of the day for as long as Australia had been settled by Europeans. There was a need to establish a court which had a fairly formal structure so that property settlements particularly, which involved large amounts of money and Queen's Counsel and the like, could be dealt with by a fairly high powered tribunal. I believe that there was also a need in a few cases to have a court which basically had the trappings and form of the traditional higher courts so that in those instances where particularly difficult litigants were involved they would feel that a body with great weight and power was making decisions. However, I believe that since that time the environment in which the Family Court operates has changed quite dramatically. We now can look at the proceedings of the Family Court to see whether they cannot be affected in a more efficient fashion than has occurred to date. There is now a need for less formality in most cases, for less rigidity and for a form which allows a great deal more flexibility.

Essentially, the Family Court deals with two situations-those involving fundamental and irreconcilable conflicts and those where conflict is at a minimum and can be quarantined. In rare cases, conflict does not exist at all at the Family Court level. It is interesting to note that 10 per cent of cases now require a hearing; in other words, 90 per cent of the cases that come before the Family Court are settled without an adversary court proceeding. Further, although the number of applications has been stable at around 40,000 per year since 1977, the cost of the administration of the Family Law Act has gone up astronomically over that period. Cost escalations have occurred notwithstanding the trend towards applicants conducting their own divorce proceedings. For example, to illustrate that point, I mention to the Committee that in 1983 one-third of all applicants conducted their own proceedings, as against 28.6 per cent the year before. Those are the latest figures that I could find, but they certainly illustrate the fact that more and more people are conducting their own proceedings before the Family Court.

Interestingly, in Western Australia, where the State Family Court exercises Federal jurisdiction, in 1983 half of the applicants conducted their own proceedings. Those figures tell us that in 90 per cent of cases, a less formal, less structured proceeding could be used, leading to a more efficient, less coercive and cheaper system of family law in this country. What type of system should it be? It could possibly be a two-tiered system, involving an informal counselling and conciliation procedure, with some type of voluntary arbitration for the 90 per cent of the cases that do not appear to involve major conflict, and the more formal Family Court structure, which would deal with those difficult cases which would be referred to it when serious conflict was found to exist by the officers at the lower tier of the system.

It is interesting to note that, as I recall it, the original proposals for the Family Court provided for a two-tiered system of justices-senior judges and more junior judges. Although we still have senior judges and other judges, I understand that the proceedings do not work as they were originally intended to with the two-tiered system, with the more senior judges dealing with the more complicated and difficult matters where conflict was involved and the ordinary judges dealing with the less complicated matters where less conflict was involved.

I believe that the benefits of a two-tiered system would be great and the cost savings would be large. By quarantining the 10 per cent of most difficult cases so that they would be the only cases dealt with by judges, the number of judges needed in that jurisdiction could be reduced significantly. Apart from the savings in salaries and fixed costs that could be made through this reform, it would also involve drastic savings in the costs of security services now needed to protect Family Court judges.

I understand that from 1 July of this year it is anticipated that the combined costs of the New South Wales Police and the Australian Federal Police involved in protecting Family Court judges could total more than $4m for the ensuing 12 months. Obviously, any reductions in the number of judges would save considerably on that amount. As well, the introduction of a less formal procedure for the 90 per cent of cases that do not end up in serious conflict could mean that more of them would be handled by the appellants without assistance from lawyers, and hence it would mean cost savings to them and to the system. Of course, in some States there is still a considerable number of cases in which legal aid is involved and, therefore, possibly quite a deal of savings could be made in relation to legal aid. If the less adversary process were to be adopted at the first tier of proceedings, it could be assumed that cases would begin and would conclude much more quickly, thus saving on administrative costs.

I have mentioned these matters tonight because I believe that there are opportunities for considerable savings to the Government in the Family Court area. I believe that the system is not operating as effectively as it could. I use the world `effectively' carefully, because I do not want to give the impression that in this area of great trauma and great difficulty, which I am sure is recognised by everybody, I am simply seeking to apply mechanical cost saving measures. I am not suggesting that at all, but I think that there are steps that can be taken within the existing framework to ensure that the system works better from the point of view of the litigants, that it works in a more cost-effective way from the point of view of the Government and that, overall, we can have a much better system. It is nearly 10 years since the Family Court began operating. For those of us who can remember the system that operated prior to the new system it is fair to say that the new Family Court system has worked quite well.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a disaster.

—It has not been a disaster. The honourable member has obviously not had any experience of the system that prevailed prior to the introduction of the new Family Court system. Whilst the tragedy of judges and their wives being killed was not with us-
—That is where it is a disaster.

—It may well be a disaster, possibly, in relation to one person in one State who has disrupted the whole system. In my view the system in States apart from New South Wales has worked very well.
