They did the same with franchises. They sold these franchises for $30,000 plus 5 per cent of gross turnover and another 10 per cent of gross turnover for advertising and promotion.

The sort of money that was taken can be shown by the figures. In six centres-two in New South Wales, three in Queensland and one in Victoria-these people took out $1.5m in three months. For instance, in Preston they took out $204,327; in North Sydney, $232,435; and in Rockhampton, $224,425. These crooks-that is what they are, criminals-took out something like $15m from unsuspecting Australians right across the board. I suggest that there is a need for an inquiry. There ought to be an inquiry into the ANZ Bank's part in this matter as well because it was telling people that they would not have to pay interest. The bank was also giving credit to centres that actually were starting up after other centres in Victoria had failed. We also had a situation where there is no credit check on any of the people applying. There were instances where up to 100 people were given approval over the phone. The money was immediately paid to the Vigor organisations; yet the people heard nothing from the ANZ Bank for months and months. People were duped; they were told they could get out of their membership. In fact, they could not. It was a blatant lie. They were forced into loans.

In a survey carried out throughout central Queensland and other parts of Queensland hundreds of people stated in writing that they were told by the Vigor centres that they had to use ANZ Bankcard. There are known instances where cash payments were refused. These people were also conned because they were told, for instance, that there would be no interest payments on any of the money that they would pay by way of this loan. Hundreds of people said that they went into this scheme only because ANZ was behind it. I believe that the Australian market-place has been a haven for con merchants for far too long. It is my hope that, given the establishment of a select committee of inquiry into the collapse of the fitness and aerobic industry in 1984, this Parliament can strike a blow for consumer justice that will be a warning and a deterrent to this nation's white collar criminals for decades to come. But we must start here. There must be an inquiry because it is quite obvious from the interjections from the honourable member for North Sydney and his colleagues that they will protect the white collar criminals of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honour- able members for their contribution. This has been a wide-ranging debate. People who practise the law have all sorts of cases put before them. I now realise, having listened to honour able members, that they all have particular matters that they want addressed. Let me commence where my distinguished colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) just finished, that is, with the Trade Practices Act. I am very conscious of the fact that many honourable members have had complaints from consumers about matters relating to consumer protection. The honourable member for Capricornia, who is one of the leading representatives of the consumer movement in Queensland, has been very anxious to ensure that this piece of legislation protects consumers from fraud. I am very pleased to be able to say that in the present proposals, there is a protection for those who are deceived. That protection not only goes to those who might have been the originators of the perception but also extends liability to those who provide the credit. Some responsibilities are now being looked at in terms of that Act. I am sure that when that matter is considered by the Parliament the honourable member will be pleased with the result.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not a great deal of time but I would like briefly to touch on other matters. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) raised two issues. The first issue he raised related to family law and the problems faced by the courts. The honourable member for Fisher comes from Queensland. As far as my Department and I are aware, whilst there are always difficulties in family law-difficulties relating to the problems of people, the problems of custody and the problems of property-there is certainly no problem in the courts in Queensland. In fact, in terms of results it is one of the better managed jurisdictions without perhaps having the pressures of some of the other States. Whilst I can understand that the honourable gentleman feels that in his view there is a change in the law, because the fault has been taken out of the question of family law, it ought to be put on record that that piece of legislation was not passed on party lines. It crossed all party lines. Those of us who were here at the time will recall that many people had different points of view on the final piece of legislation. Many people did not like it but the majority did and those in the majority came from all sections of the Parliament.

Although I find some of the problems of interest, I think the issue is that the pressures are great. Perhaps the court was set up in too much of a hurry in 1976. Perhaps there was not an adequate availability of suitable premises. I am not complaining, but I think that was a factor. I agree also when Sir Harry Gibbs says that some consideration ought to be given to personnel who take on the responsibility of family law. I must say that I find it difficult to attract people to go to the family law court because of the attitude adopted, probably very unfairly, that there is something wrong with the court. There is nothing wrong with the court but there can be a lot of difficulties with a court that deals with human behaviour when people are not prepared, to some extent, to accept the verdict of a judge when it comes particularly to custody and also when they disagree with issues of decision made in property settlements. Divorce means that the parents are going to separate and we have the inevitable tension, conflict and heat generated by the fact that each considers himself or herself not to be in the wrong, yet a judge has to make a decision. It is not an easy task.

It has been very disappointing to find that violence has come about, particularly in the Sydney region. An enormous amount of resources and time is being devoted to protecting the judges in that area to detect those responsible for the murders of people and the attempted murders of others. It is a very serious problem. I have been talking to the judges and I find them very co-operative and understanding of the problems they face. I must say that they try very hard to get the message across that it is a court in which they want to assist people. As was said by some other speakers earlier, it is a court that was designed for compassion and conciliation but it is very difficult if at times that does not come through in the conduct of the court. Of course, there is also the inevitable problem of the disenchantment by litigants as to the result.

I think it would be helpful if we could persuade the Parliament that perhaps we might have expected too much of judges who have no judicial responsibilities other than to sit in the Family Court of Australia every day. I do not think they need to be given other judicial work. I think it would break the monotony and help to assist the court. I do not think it is in our best interests to have an exclusive Family Court of Australia. I think it ought to be like any other court. I would be very anxious to upgrade the status of the judges to that of Federal judges, but there is a resistance to that on the basis that they may not be able to do all the work of Federal judges. I think I should be entitled to try and in future appointments there might be the opportunity to work in major areas. That would go very close to what the Chief Justice was on about.

It is also important in appeal cases that there be judges of Federal Court status to talk about appeals and I think that would be accepted. Then we might break down the barrier that has been very unfairly created in the sense that the court has no real understanding of the problems of the family. What we are about, of course, when we talk about the responsibility of judicial office is the fact that a judgment has to be made and that very experienced people are there who can make those judgments. We cannot really solve the problems of a family that is torn apart by difficulties in its past with a legal result that it come back together. That would require other than a legal judgment. A judgment directing that the parties resume married life is of no consequence at all to them. They want to know what will be the result from the point of view of property or custody, and that requires the wisdom of Solomon. The issue is to get the parties to accept the fact that a judgment has to be made and that it is not one of revenge. It must be one of attempted apportionment, of where the future remnants of the family can continue to make their respective lives and particularly, as far as the children are concerned, to get the respect, love and affection of both parents. That would be a remarkable result.

It has not always been possible to achieve that. Those of us who know the difficulties of the divorce court and the sadness and sorrow of children whose parents have separated understand that. The difficulty is that we find too much emphasis placed on what is wrong with the court. Let me give it high praise for the work it does. It performs very well. Ninety per cent of the cases are settled, which is a very remarkable effort for those assisting that court. I must say that the court, through the judges, the registrars and the officers of my Attorney- General's Department, and with my own interest, are working out ways and means whereby we might be able to streamline the procedures to try to prevent too much adversary combat. If the parties can come to a settlement on the matter we must encourage that. The registrars are playing a very good role in that area and I think we are beginning to see an improvement in not having too much red tape or too many difficulties in getting matters dealt with. But there are always those cases which will never be solved unless they go to court, and I am anxious to work in the area that will bring about a solution to those, I hope by melding that court into a Federal jurisdiction and not having it in such an exclusive jurisdiction. It will take a fair bit of advocacy on my part with those in the judiciary who feel there are problems in that area.

I point to the issues: At present there are 60 uniformed New South Wales policemen in Sydney guarding the courts and judges. That is just an impossible continuous allocation of resources that has to be used and we have to find a solution to that. It is not in the interests of the judges, their safety and their families, and I can well understand why people could feel there is a real problem in being invited to sit on that court. I think we can get away from this if we can get into the areas I have mentioned; that is, not exclusive jurisdiction and not having the court identified as a special building.

The honourable member for Fisher is not present, and I do not mind that, but he seemed to think that the setting up of the Human Rights Commission was solely my fault and that the people on it were solely appointed by me, whereas in fact it was created by the Fraser Government and all appointments were made by that Government. I think the honourable member might at least recognise that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he did say that actually.
—Did he? I accept the honourable member's views although I do not think he had the benefit of listening to him in here.
—I listened in my office; I listened to every word.

—There must have been some interception in the communications system because it did not come through here. I think the Commission is trying very hard in a very difficult area but at the same time we are dealing with the question of human rights. I do not agree with a number of its decisions, and I have said so, and the Government does not either. Nevertheless, from the point of view of dealing with the issue of human rights, the former Government created a commission, as it should have and as it was obliged to do as we sit on the Human Rights Commission in the United Nations. We endeavour to get the message through to all countries that people have rights and governments must recognise them. I know the Commission endeavours to do that in a wide-ranging area. It does it in the areas not only of Federal and State laws but also relating to the rights of people in terms of employment, where there may be racial or sexual discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very hopeful that when the present Bill goes through the Parliament we will reconstitute the Human Rights Commission. I am anxious that the President of that Commission be a Federal judge and occupy the position for a limited period rather than permanently so that again there can be some understanding of the fact by a number of judges as to how the human rights legislation can work. I look forward to that as a challenge to the legal profession and I am sure that there will be recognition of the value of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. We agreed that we would ratify that Covenant. The previous Government did that and we supported it. The means of ratification was to bring into existence the Human Rights Commission-we are now going to reconstitute that-as well as an Australian Bill of Rights, which is now before the Parliament and about which I will say no more.

The honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) referred to the Family Court. He referred, quite properly, to the Western Australian situation, where parties are encouraged to settle their differences and to appear in person. I must say that it is one of the most successful Family Courts in Australia. Some 68 per cent of litigants appear in person and matters are frequently solved in pre-trial conferences. The parties are able to get some legal advice if they wish, but if matters can be solved without too much legal interference, better solutions obviously are achieved there. The honourable member mentioned problems of exclusivity of jurisdiction and difficulties with security, to which I have adverted. The Court is performing very well in South Australia. The additional provision for getting the parties together without too much legal involvement, with the registrars holding conferences, is now being used readily. The number of cases has been reduced because of this concept, which came into being only in July. Nevertheless, we want to overcome the problems I mentioned earlier which might be causing difficulties, problems such as the nature of the exclusive jurisdiction and the wrong impression that the Court is deemed to be inferior in terms of being able to judge as other courts do. That is not right.

In that context I make the point that perhaps we can do better in making marriages more successful if we devote more resources to pre-marriage counselling guidance and education. The final position comes down to the parties themselves having an understanding, a compatibility and an appreciation of the pressures which arise in the married situation, particularly where children are involved. There are also difficulties caused by economic hardship, loss of employment and other pressures which can affect the family. If all those matters could be put into perspective properly prior to marriage, I am sure it would assist. Nevertheless, strong efforts are being made in the area of family law.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) said that the Human Rights Commission must have been established by a Labor Government. I can understand the problems, but the Human Rights Commission does not produce reports because the Government requests it to do so. That is not necessarily so; in fact, it is usually to the contrary. It produces reports, as required by its charter, on questions such as illegal immigrants, Aborigines and homosexual reunions, but this Parliament makes the law and is guided by public opinion as to what is fair and reasonable. The Human Rights Commission has a charter to produce reports, and I remind the honourable gentleman that the Commission was established by the Fraser Government. That fact should be recognised in the debate here.

Criticism was also made of reports being received in respect of affirmative action. That matter is being discussed, not from the point of view of any legislative requirement that it be made mandatory but from the point of view that people interested in giving women fair employment opportunities, as is their right, are talking with the business community and agreeing that there can be opportunities to consider equal opportunity or equity in employment. I think the business community is agreed that there are plenty of opportunities where it can indicate to its members that they should not overlook the fact that because an employee happens to be a woman she would not have the necessary skill and application for the job. The case is to the contrary, as we all know. When we look around, both in the Parliament and elsewhere, we see women in our society making a splendid contribution. What we are talking about in this area should not be criticised; it should be supported. Opportunities have to be given to women in employment be cause there is no doubt that they have been discriminated against in the past and that they deserve as much encouragement as anybody in our society. That is what the movement is all about and I think it will attract support across the length and breadth of the nation. When legislation is introduced, consideration should be given not to making affirmative action mandatory but to mentioning it if it is not being applied.

The honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) effectively dealt with the issue of organised crime. He was the only honourable member to touch on that matter. It is a most serious issue, not only in our nation but throughout the world. Enormous resources have to be devoted to prosecuting criminals. The Director of Public Prosecutions carries out that role, and is very busy and successful in bringing criminals to trial. It takes a long time and a fair amount of effort to get the necessary evidence. The National Crime Authority has worked effectively in creating task forces of lawyers and others who have skills relating to monetary transactions and can chase what Mr Costigan called the money trail. Together with the Taxation Office, they have been able to collate information that will lead to substantial benefits for the Australian community. There is no doubt that the amount of money involved runs into millions of dollars. The intelligence behind these organisations is not limited to Australia; it is international. It involves organisations such as the Mafia and others whose penetration is improving, regrettably, in all nations of the world.

The recent conference in Milan, dealing with organised crime, identified these problems in every nation of the world. It was realised that the narcotics trade particularly is increasing and that young victims are deliberately being addicted to drugs by those involved in the organisations. They become a problem not only to themselves but to society because their drug addition leads to other crime in trying to service that addiction. There needs to be co-operation by means of mutual assistance treaties, which will provide the opportunity for a country to ask for information which might be available in the financial area. Information could be given and received to help in dealing with organised crime. The questions of taking evidence overseas and the forfeiture of assets are also important. In other words, there has to be a massive attack in this area. I welcome the support of the State governments, but it is a major issue facing all nations of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you find Trimbole?

—We are having a lot of difficulty, for reasons that the right honourable member might understand. The amount of money involved would run into millions of dollars. The right honourable gentleman mentioned a person's name. As a matter of interest, in the case in Ireland he was defended by three Queen's Counsel and two juniors, which would have cost a little bit of money. It has been suggested that assets might have been available in a neutral country, famous for that, running into substantial sums of money. It might interest the right honourable member to know that when this person left Australia on a false passport, it was thought that he also knew the countries with which we had no extradition treaties. His legal intelligence is pretty good. I am happy to say that I have completed another eight extradition treaties, so that we shall be able to deal with these matters, and there are many more to go. It is difficult to get the countries of the world to move quickly, but it is because we have altered the techniques, agreeing with the question of a statement of the offence as being reasonable in the evidence submitted, that I think we were able to get a lot of movement there at present.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the honourable member for Lowe for raising this most important matter. It will take a lot of the time of this country's legal and other resources to deal with these matters. The Australian Taxation Office has a role to play, as have the banks on the question on opening of accounts and identities, and the following of the money trail. There will be brought to trial people who perhaps would never have thought that they would be in a court, because they are of a very sophisticated class, and not the usual type of criminal-although they certainly know how to make money, and they batten on to the unfortunate young. If one is looking at drug addiction, it is tragic to find that most of those caught up in addiction have come from broken homes. That is not axiomatic, but it follows through from the Family Court structure, and the issue of love and affection really comes into the human being having the stability and maturity to be able to deal with the pressures. If that love and affection is not present in their formative period of life, these people seem to be prone to addiction. Another interesting study-which is not proven, but it is suggested that it has some merit-shows that of the heroin addicts, 80 per cent had alcoholic parents. There is then a further factor in addiction that arises from the fact that the home might not have been going as well as it should.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did the study?

—It is a Sydney study. It is yet to be proven, but that is one of the issues. I just comment on it in the context of dealing with crime to say that in many cases, particularly regarding heroin, most of the addicts are under the age of 23 and most would not live beyond the age of 30. So there is a dreadful problem for our society. One can imagine what it does to their parents and others caught up in this issue. As honourable members would know, it was not prevalent in the 1960s; it has become more obvious in the 1980s. That is an issue that we are facing.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), the shadow Attorney-General, raised a number of very important issues. He wanted to know about my constitutional commission. I think that I have said what I am about to say in the Convention debates. I went there this year asking that the Convention be adjourned for two years to enable an alternative method of constitutional reform to be considered. I think that the honourable member would agree with me that the only way in which we shall get constitutional reform in this country is on a bipartisan basis, and that it is very difficult to get bipartisanship in this area. Honourable members opposite would recognise that because, whilst at times we might have appeared to be bipartisan, when we reached the hustings we were anything but that. Of course, inevitably, the people do not want to say that they understand the situation if we appear to be disagreeing on the issue.

That has been my criticism of the Convention itself. It has been meeting for 12 years and it has not had a lot of success. We have been able to give votes to the Territories. We have been able to fill casual vacancies in the Senate. There was one other matter which escapes me at present. Honourable members opposite would recall that when they were in government they did not even call the Convention together between 1978 and 1983, so it was not a high priority.

The Cabinet has agreed with me that we ought to try to see whether we can get together some of the people in Australia who would have particular skills and would also be representative of the Australian people-on both sides of the political fence-but who also have communicative skills in order to be able to communicate with the people on what it is all about and, to see whether we can get a new or revised document. The honourable gentleman appears to be a bit concerned because I might have mentioned the name of Tom Keneally. I make no apologies for that. I think that he is a very effective writer. He understands the heart and soul of Australia. I must tell the honourable gentleman that in all the meetings in Australia held for a new constitution on the basis of democracy, particularly following the 1975 results, Keneally was always there and taking a leading role. It is not as though one just plucked him out of the air on the basis that he might not have shown any interest; he is very interested in talking about Australia as a nation and he feels that he has a contribution to make. As honourable members opposite would appreciate, although they may not necessarily agree, I think that there are opportunities for people to talk about a constitution and how it would represent the aspirations of the Australian people, and in my view Keneally could fulfil that role.

I have mentioned the name Garrett not because I have ever met the gentleman but because young people relate to him. He also happens to be legally trained. If one looks at his lyrics-not that I encourage honourable members to devote a lot of time to them-one sees that he talks about the wishes and the needs of the people. If honourable members talk to young people, as I am sure they do, they will find them being very anxious to get the truth on what we are about in Australia. They have a great respect for each other, and to some extent they regard themselves, because they are young, as needing to be considered in the terms of documents that we write about their rights and their future. So that was an aspect of mentioning that name.

I have never met Ray Martin, but I regard him as also being a first class communicator, particularly to an older group of people who relate to him. He also has skills, and I was pleased to hear him say that he felt that he would like to take an interest. Of course, they will not be the only people involved. I endeavoured to name the type of people who would be the nucleus in regard to looking at a document that might be suitable for Australia. I mentioned two former Prime Ministers, from different sides of the Parliament. I emphasise that on the basis of bipartisanship. I also mentioned the fact that I would be very anxious to get a retired High Court judge as chairman. At present I am waiting for an answer. If I can get that answer-and I hope that I will get it-I shall be able to go right ahead. At the moment, I want to talk about the calibre of the people who would attract a lot of legal weight in regard to the aspects of how they saw this document in practice. Whether they be High Court judges or parliamentarians, they have lived with this document and the problems and the problems of it. There must be recognition of the States. Consideration would need to be given to that. There must be recognition and consideration of local government. But the nucleus would be small, and in my view there would need to be some sub-committees that could make an input.

The honourable member asked about the role for the present Convention. If it wished to continue, I would not be able to stop it. I would invite it to make a submission to the commission. That might be what it could do. But it is quite counter-productive for the Convention to be, as it was in recent efforts, with the surprising support of the Opposition, urging that we return to State excise taxes. That was one of the resolutions passed. I cannot imagine anyone in Australia wanting to have two types of taxes. People regard taxation as being onerous when it is levied by the Federal authority, but to think that they would now have a State tax as well would cause no end of trouble. I wait with bated breath for the Opposition to come forward with a policy at the next Federal election urging that there also be State excises; yet that is the sort of conduct that goes on. I am only stating this in terms of trying to get some understanding of what we are about.

Finally, the honourable gentleman raised a number of valid issues in regard to legal aid. Substantial amounts of money are being paid in legal aid. One matter that the honourable gentleman raised was on the basis of how much work was being done in-house. It would have been a difficult question for me to answer, but fortunately I have just looked at a letter that has been put in front of me. It relates to legal aid, and it says:

In 1984-85, 37.3 per cent of the total expenditure of all major legal aid bodies in Australia was devoted to salaries and administrative costs, while 62.7 per cent went towards payment to private legal practitioners.
Of course, one could immediately say that that might be a pretty excessive administrative cost; but when one looks at the question of administrative cost, one sees that it means the salaried staff.
The salaried staff conducted 217,658 advice interviews and 34,097 duty lawyer interviews and appeared in 75,364 duty lawyer matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are a litigious nation.

—We are a very litigious nation. I make the point that the staff were not just sitting down looking at the files. They were really in action. The honourable gentlemen would know that the funding the Commonwealth provides is the major funding. However, the States also make a contribution. Our funding is in the vicinity of $72m. Last year, 70.9 per cent of the referred matters went to private practitioners and 29.1 per cent was in-house. The number of persons assisted by Commonwealth funding last year totalled 86,705. There are difficulties in the area of legal aid. The honourable member for North Sydney was probing the issue. I can understand that; it is fair. There is just not enough money to give legal aid in all circumstances. The task force report is out. It will be noticed that the major contribution has been made by the Commonwealth, as it has to be. Some States have very little input at all. They do not have any resources. New South Wales has a substantial input because it uses the money that is obtained from solicitors' trust accounts which runs into about $24m. That does not apply, for example, to South Australia. Very little money is contributed by some States.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, the structure I have inherited is one of State commissions except in New South Wales, with which we are still negotiating a merger. The idea with the commissions is that the legal profession be represented on them. I place a lot of value on the profession. It does a lot of work for nothing and it seldom gets recognition for that. However, it is important to get its members to take an interest in how we might best deliver the $70m. On that basis we can get some results. If I can get the profession to talk to me about how best to do so in the various States I am sure that we would get co-operation. There would be occasions when particularly the young members of the profession would get very little indeed to appear in the local courts, but at least people would be represented. Regrettably, at present there is no legal aid for pleas of guilty or for committals. That poses a problem for us. In many cases one could be encouraged to visit duty solicitors and get some advice. I am sure that the profession would co-operate. I would be anxious to explore that with the profession. The sum of $38m in legal aid goes on family law matters, which is very surprising, considering that only 7 per cent or 8 per cent of matters are litigated. Again, there is an outrageous expenditure to the extent of the needs of others.

There is a difficulty in trying to get the best results for people. I am very appreciative of the support given by the legal aid duty personnel as well as by the profession. It is a continuous effort. The fact is that we would all agree that we cannot give as much money as is needed. However, we would all expect it to be given to those in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the $5m reduction?

—I thank the honourable member for reminding me. The $5m was a reallocation within the same portfolio. As I understand it, the relevant document, which is not readily available, would show that there was a reduction in division 175 from memory. One will find that payments to the State commissions have been substantially increased. In other words, there has been a substantial increase in legal aid. The item concerning the $5m is merely a book entry, if I may use that term. The State commissions have received substantial increases to which the $5m went towards. There is a difficulty in that the State commissions are anxious to reduce their contributions. I have just had the departmental explanatory notes handed to me. The appropriation under division 175 for the Australian Legal Aid Office has been reduced. However, there has been a substantial increase in division 819.02, legal aid commissions, formerly division 175.3.03, which has gone from $37.1m to $56.2m. The $5m relates to that area. I think that addresses most of the matters. I thank honourable members for their contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, in 10 minutes there is little chance of my doing as I would like. I guess that in many ways I should initially comment by saying that it is a great pity that we have this form of examination of the Estimates. As one who lived under another system and did not like it particularly, I still think that it is a pity that there is not an opportunity for greater dialogue. The contribution just made by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) on the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department identified some of the advantage we would have if there were some exchange of views on some of the details of expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: In my remarks I will very briefly canvass an assessment of the strategic situation and then relate it to two areas that concern me in the estimates for the Department of Defence. In regard to the strategic situation, we know that Mr Paul Dibb is shortly to make a contribution. I would be interested to hear the view of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on the rate of progress there and what is going to happen about the Paul Dibb review. I see a number of problems. My colleague the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, is going to talk about ANZUS. We know of the situation concerning fishing rights for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in Kiribati and the problems with the defence co-operation program. I am not too sure of the rate of progress of the defence co-operation program. However, I am most concerned that the DCP be maintained. Some political prejudice has been shown about some of the aid programs in some countries, but for my money the DCP is a tremendously valuable way by which this country can help other countries in the region to develop their defence capability to enhance our overall regional security. Through DCP there is an opportunity for many countries to play some role with us. One way we can contain the impact of the Soviet fishing agreement with Kiribati is to make sure that we also continue to co-operate with Kiribati in the way it develops its own intrinsic defence capability. That allows me to refer very briefly to the Pacific patrol boat. I will return to it. I do not feel that it is adequate for the sort of aid programs I have in mind for that part of the world.

Having mentioned the Soviet Union and ANZUS in passing, there are a number of particular problems that I hope Mr Dibb addresses. The circumstances of the hijacking of the Achille Lauro have shown the degree to which terrorism is rife. It is a threat henceforth not only to aircraft but also, presumably, shipping as piracy on the high seas is now possible, having been shown already to have occurred. I was delighted to hear the Acting Prime Minister say that he intended to contact President Reagan and commend the Americans on their apprehension of the four hijackers. I believe that there is an enormous problem unless something can be done about terrorism and hijacking. Let no one in this place be mistaken that the situation has been allowed to drift because internationally so little action seems in the past to have been possible. It is important to know that action relies very much on the defence forces.

The relevance to Mr Dibb is that while it is true that, through the co-operation between various police forces around the world, some action can be taken against criminal figures, when it comes to terrorism essentially it has to be units such as our own Special Air Service Regiment in its counter-terrorist role to which attention needs to be drawn and from which assistance must be found if there is to be any apprehension of these people and if they are to be brought to justice in the normal course. Co-operation between countries is essential and Australia has a real role to play.

I am also worried about the situation in New Caledonia and between Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya. It is terribly important that we realise that the defence threat in this part of the world as a result is not just quiescent. It is not a matter of the Soviet Union being about to invade Australia. It is not a matter of there suddenly being a situation whereby any of us can see the prospects, even given what is happening in ANZUS, of there being an immediate threat to our territorial sovereignty here or in any of our island territories. But the strategic situation is changing and my problem in looking at these estimates is that there are a number of areas where I think the Government's reaction has been less than adequate.

The first of those I wanted to address was the concern I have at the way in which manpower is being run down without what I regard as a proper concern for reasonable personnel strengths. There is no doubt that the consequence of the Government's decision not to replace HMAS Melbourne and to scrap the fixed-wing aviation capability in the Navy has had an impact on naval personnel. To be 1,600 down in two Budgets is to be down a lot of personnel. If we are going to reduce numbers in that way, I am afraid that there will be an impact on personnel and musterings. Of course, it has been assisted by the number of people unemployed in the community and, as a result, there have been some problems in maintaining younger recruits. I would be interested in figures the Minister might have about the degree to which there has been re-enlistment because senior sailors and senior non-commissioned officers have been re-enlisting, although I believe that that is changing because the rate of resignations has increased due to the attitudes the Government has generally taken to wages and salaries and terms and conditions of employment. I am quite concerned that at the moment there will be only a 5.9 per cent pay rise and that it was not retrospective. I believe there are problems with pay, conditions and housing. I know that the Budget provides some money for housing. I welcome the Government's move in that area and there is a totally bipartisan attitude towards the necessity to improve housing. I certainly would look to trying to sell much of the existing service housing instead of just repairing it. We have to address that problem when we look at the personnel situation.

My concern is not only that the Navy strength is down by 1,600. We are also told now that the Army is to be reduced by 677 positions, and it is all for the sake of re-equipping. I do not have time to go into the detail of it, but I think it important we understand that the Reserves are weak and that there is a very real problem in trying to find adequate personnel to meet reasonable requirements. While I compliment the officers and crew of HMAS Perth and HMAS Adelaide for the role they played in the Hoelien attempted rescue and while Rear Admiral Ian Knox and his officers and men did a tremendous job in generally presenting the case to the Australian nation at 1985 shop window, there is a problem in trying to achieve adequate numbers to face the task. Sadly, when we look at the teeth to tail ratio we realise that Service numbers have declined. The number of civilians has increased but there is an even greater concern. The number of civilians has gone up from 38,775, including 15,000 in the Department of Defence Support, at 30 June 1983, to 39,102, without Department of Defence Support, in the comparable period of 1985. I know that we have to employ contractors. I know that there are problems where it is necessary for us to identify jobs that need not be duplicated within the Services. I think there is a need to try to introduce greater efficiency of manpower use and, indeed, utilisation of funds. The Minister and I have privately had some discussions on this, but I do not accept that we can reduce the number of Service personnel, have a weakened Reserve and be able to face the sort of threat situation I see about us. I speak of a threat with a small `t' and I have explained the anti-terrorism role and other roles. While I understand the development of a battalion in the Army with parachuting capability is a step towards perhaps improving our general ability to respond to terrorist situations, that is not its immediate or prime role. We have to look very carefully at the personnel area and I do not believe it is adequate at the moment.

The area I really wanted to talk about was procurement. Perhaps I can highlight my concerns. I refer to the FA18 position. I have seen McDonnell Douglas's statement that the wing stress or tail pin stress which apparently has developed is something to do with the carry-through box. I would be interested to hear the remarks of the Minister on that. I think it very important that the Australian community be satisfied, as I am, that the FA18 is an excellent aircraft and that it has a very important role to play. I hope that the Minister has maintained his view that the F111s should be upgraded because they also have a role.

I wanted to comment on the scrapping of project Waler and my concern about the A10 or Air Force trainer, the former Wamira project. I have some very serious doubts about the wisdom of upgrading the M113 family of armoured personnel carriers. I think it would have been far better, particularly for design and development capability in Australia, to have proceeded with Project Waler. I believe it is essential that the A10 should go to the Hawker De Havilland group and that it should proceed. I think it is an excellent aircraft. Unless we do that, design and development skills in the Australian aircraft industry will be virtually extinct. Frankly, I do not believe we can afford that, given the general pressures there are on the Australian manufacturing industry and the problems with trying to maintain the defence capability in this country. I believe that there is a requirement to upgrade Australian ability in procurement. I would like to hear the Minister's view on that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Labor Government is not concerned only with equipment purchases. They were neglected for years by the Opposition, who worried only about capital equipment and did not give a damn for the personnel involved and the people they represented. Major housing programs started in previous years are also continuing at Holsworthy, Rockingham, Puckapunyal and Darwin.

Consistent with practice in recent years, the 1985-86 defence outlay includes a provision of $162m as an allowance for the effects of possible wage and salary increases. The overall amount provided is not a forecast of likely individual arbitration decisions nor a statement of the Government's position on particular pay claims. It is a provision aimed essentially at achieving a more realistic presentation in aggregate terms of the likely budget outcome. The Government will seek appropriations through the Parliament in the normal way to meet the requirements flowing from such pay cases. It should not be forgotten that it was the Hawke Labor Government that introduced the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. No longer will Defence Force personnel be dependent upon the whims of people like the right honourable member for New England to obtain wage justice. Defence Force personnel will not be forgotten again in future and their conditions will not be reduced beyond the normal working conditions of other people in this country. They will not go backwards, as they did under the previous Government, and there is no reason why defence personnel should go backwards. There is no reason why they should be forced to live in the miserable conditions that they put up with in previous years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why have you forgotten about them for two and a half years?

—The right honourable member for New England can sit back and bleat forth but he knows what he did to them. The Army knows and the Defence Force personnel generally know what he did. That was something the Opposition could never do and under its current policy of cutting expenditure it is something it would never do in the future-if this country were unlucky enough to have the Opposition in government again.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see that at Puckapunyal a total of $3.94m is allocated for housing, an armoured centre and training kitchens, which are near completion. New projects that will begin in 1985-86 include nine houses and a range control complex. There is an additional important program. Personnel are putting together a very good soil conservation program to repair the damage which existed for many years under the previous Government. The Opposition damn near destroyed the place. About 60 per cent of the land was not usable under the previous Administration and it has cost nearly $10m to restore that land as an effective operational range again. That is something the Opposition did not do in government; it was not concerned about it. The Opposition does not worry about personnel. It likes F111s, FA18s and big tanks, but it does not worry about Defence Force personnel. I can tell Opposition members now that the Defence Force personnel know what is happening. They know why they have not got good conditions, they know who did nothing for them, and they know that this Government has done a lot more for them than the Opposition ever did or ever will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The less said about the previous contribution the better. The inanities of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) were exceeded only by the ignorance. I wish to speak briefly tonight in the time available about the unravelling of ANZUS under this Government. On assuming office the Labor Government reviewed the ANZUS Treaty and decided, interestingly enough, in the Foreign Minister's own words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to an unequivocal reaffirmation of the Alliance as fundamental to our foreign and defence policies.

What is deplorable is that in having accepted the centrality of ANZUS to our foreign policy, Labor has done nothing to stop the Treaty unravelling. For more than a year now the Opposition has called on the Government to involve itself in the dispute over nuclear ships and to work for a solution to the crisis. For more than a year now the Government has stood by and done virtually nothing. We are now confronted by a situation where ANZUS is, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), inoperative, and the Treaty is liable to review should New Zealand proceed with its nuclear-free zone legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have your angry face look.

—Listen old son, we would not even know where that face of yours came from. We had to look up the Hansard to see your name. You are hardly a statesman-like character whose name is on the lips of all Australians. I will test my record in this Parliament against yours when it falls to the ground at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned the review the United States is talking about. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) is returing from Washington, having ducked and weaved and further fudged Australia's position. I ask tonight: What is the Government's position on the New Zealand legislation? What is the Government's position on a review of the pact? What is the Government's view on the current legal and operational status of the Treaty? This is not an issue on which, as the Government would wish, we can be neutral because it cuts across our fundamental security interests and those of the Western alliance. The American stand is perfectly correct. Yet this Government has no clear message to the New Zealand Government about where we stand. It has made no attempt to take a mediatory role and has made no attempt to work for a solution. Even now, no attempt is being made to dissuade New Zealand from its anti-nuclear legislation. The Prime Minister knows all this and he knows what he should have done. He wrote one letter to the New Zealand Prime Minister. When it leaked, because of his fear of the Left's reaction, he disowned the letter. He again showed the weakness of the factional compromise that has become the hallmark of the administration of Labor's foreign policy. He went back to perpetrating the big lie that this crisis was `one between New Zealand and the United States only'. It is not. It affects our interests, those of the region, and the Western alliance as a whole.

The Government has sought to justify its dereliction over ANZUS by saying that it will preserve the bilateral defence relationship between Australia and the United States. This of course misses the point. The ANZUS Treaty is now a hollow shell and we are left with something much less. The termination of defence co-operation between the United States and New Zealand has diminished Australia's security and stability as well as that of the region. The co-ordination, the intelligence sharing and defence co-operation made possible by ANZUS, and the authority that alliance membership gave each of the three partners have been vital to effective regional responses to the Soviet Union's attempts to make strategic inroads into the Pacific. A bilateral relationship between Australia and the United States on the one hand and between Australia and New Zealand on the other is a very poor substitute for the tripartite influence made possible by ANZUS.

The fact that the Hawke Government allowed ANZUS to become inoperative will only encourage renewed Soviet attempts to make new strategic inroads into the Pacific, while hampering our capacity to resist the erosion of regional integrity. The unravelling of ANZUS has caused justifiable concern to our friends in South East Asia and the Pacific. The sort of warning we have given about Soviet interest in wanting to see ANZUS unravelled has not come just from us. Let me read to honourable members what Paul Dibb, the Federal Government's newly appointed defence adviser, stated recently:

The Soviet Union would like to see the ANZUS alliance system disrupted in its favour and the close relationship that has developed between Australia, New Zealand and the United States with the ASEAN countries and with the nations of Oceania destroyed. The importance of ANZUS to the USSR needs to be clearly understood.

This is not a viewpoint expressed solely by the Opposition; it has been expressed by the Government's defence adviser. What should be made crystal clear is that it is the United States presence and the ANZUS pact which have underpinned the region's economic dynamism.

Any weakening of the ability of the United States to perform its role could seriously undermine the stability and economic prospects of the region. Furthermore, the regional role of ANZUS cannot be divorced from its global role. It has been an important link in the network of alliances that make up the greater Western alliance. We should also be clear about the value of the Treaty as our ultimate guarantee and about what Labor has put at risk. The intention of the United States has long been that it would help Australia in the event of a serious military conflict. As recently as last year, Mr Paul Wolfowitz, the United States Assistant Secretary of State, East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said:

Let there be no doubt in the mind of any potential adversary that an armed attack on an ally would require, and would receive from the allies, full and prompt fulfilment of the ANZUS security commitment, including, when necessary, military.

There is a further compelling reason why the existence of a healthy ANZUS is important to our security, and that is its deterrent value. The fact is that the very existence of ANZUS means that any country seeking to take military action against Australia would also have to take into consideration Australia's relationship with the United States, and the nature of the support that the United States would extend under the Treaty. All this could now be lost.

The United States proposal to review the ANZUS Treaty should New Zealand go ahead with its anti-nuclear legislation is an understandable if regrettable step in order to clarify the present situation-a situation where the Treaty is falling into some form of operational and legal vacuum. Yet what is the Government's position? Once again it has remained silent and it has put its factional problems ahead of our fundamental security interests.

The Government should have acted earlier to prevent the situation deteriorating to such an extent. It now must act to ensure that any review does not reduce the United States guarantees to Australia under the Treaty and that any congressional intervention in the review process does not threaten Australia's interests. It should not have come to this, but a successfully conducted review process which avoids these pitfalls will be an important element in restoring ANZUS to centrality in the Australia-United States relationship.

I expect the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is present in the House, to give us at least some perception tonight of the Government's thinking on this matter. As I said at the commencement of my speech, this Government stated a year ago that ANZUS was fundamental to our security. It has watched as the ANZUS Treaty has unravelled. It is no longer operative. The United States is now threatening a review of Treaty arrangements in view of the impending New Zealand legislation; yet this Government still maintains that it is a dispute solely between the United States and New Zealand. Although the ANZUS Treaty is a three-country treaty, the Government will not inject itself into this argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—Because it is scared of the approbrium and action of the Left and Centre Left should it do so. This non-action is occurring while our country's most basic defence treaty is unravelling. It may be good enough to provide the sop to deal with factional disputes, but it is not good enough as far as I am concerned when the Government has allowed our basic defence security to reach the situation which has been deemed by the Prime Minister of this country to be non-operative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of what the former Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) had to say could be disregarded in this House this evening. Honourable members on this side of the House would agree with a number of things that he said about ANZUS. Some may agree or disagree with the statement that a bilateral relationship was a poor substitute. Basically, he was suggesting that, no matter what occurs, we should drag New Zealand-an independent country-whether it wants to or not, to the starting barrier to become a full member of ANZUS. He proposes that, no matter what New Zealand wanted, no matter what we think it should do and no matter what the United States of America, the public in Australia or the Government of Australia think they should do, we should drag New Zealand to the starting barrier. That is pure and unadulterated nonsense and the honourable member knows that, because that cannot be done to any country.

SPEECH.PARA: The ANZUS Treaty is a very important treaty. It has been part of Australia's defence background for the last 3 1/2 decades, and will continue to be so with regard to our relationships and frendship with the United States of America. I refer to the speech made by the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), when he congratulated our Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) on his answer to a question this afternoon in support of the United States retaliation against terrorism. I agree with that statement, because international thuggery has gone on for too long. When the opportunity arose-some people believe this should happen every day, but it does not-the Americans took that opportunity aboard. I suggest that, if we were in such a position, Australia would do exactly the same thing.

I am pleased to speak this evening on the Foreign Affairs portfolio. This Government has had an outstanding record in foreign relations, and it has spoken out very clearly and independently on a number of issues; namely ANZUS, Indo-China and disarmament and arms control, just to name a few. A more independent voice is being heard for the first time and Australia's foreign policy orientation is being directed more to the Asia-Pacific region. That has not always occurred, and that was especially the case during the 1950s and 1960s under Prime Minister Menzies. Indeed, the people of Australia did not see any change in focus or ideas until the Whitlam Government took office in December 1972.

Australia, geographically, is part of the South East Asia-South West Pacific region, no matter what friendships or other ties we have elsewhere. Of course, that is not to dismiss those friendships in any way. However, the fact is that we are part of one of the fastest growing regions in the world. The region has advanced economically in incredible leaps in the last decade and a half. Our economic and cultural future lies in this region. We have seen our country change a great deal in the last three decades to become a multicultural society.

Our co-operation with the Pacific states will be of great importance to us in the years ahead. Australia could find itself giving substantial assistance to many of the Pacific states in a way that not only would meet their requirements but also could not be met by the super-powers. The South Pacific Forum, although still young, is growing into a vibrant and meaningful organisation.

Whilst noting that Australia has improved a great deal over the past few years in recognising the concerns and wishes of the Pacific people, I acknowledge that much has still to be done. No region in the world is more significant to Australia than the Pacific. The infiltration of the Soviet diplomatic network into the Pacific should be of major concern to us all. Let there be no doubt that this is occurring, including a pronounced communist influence into the trade union movement in and around the Pacific region. On the other hand, I believe very strongly that the Pacific people do not need Big Brother telling them what to do or when they should do it. They need independence. They need assistance that will make them self-sufficient and self-assured of their future. It is in this area that the present tuna fishing policies being adopted by the United States cause me some concern.

Since the election of the Hawke Government we have also seen Australia's election to the United Nations Security Council. It is also appropriate to point out at this time that Australia will take its turn to chair the Council next month. It has been through the United Nations and other forums throughout the world, notably in Geneva, that Australia has pursued another very important issue, that of disarmament and arms control. This issue is undoubtedly one of the most important of our time. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of this Parliament has had this important issue as one of its references for nearly two years. As Chairman of the sub-committee that has investigated the reference of disarmament and arms control, I can verify the complex nature of the subject. The Committee should be able to present what will be a major report to the Parliament early next year.

I hope that this important forthcoming report will form the basis for the nuclear and arms control debate in this country. Whilst I cannot discuss the contents of the report until it is tabled, it is my belief that the standard of debate in Australia has generally been fairly poor. For example, `disarmament' is a word that is often misused and it can give people a false impression. Are we seriously to suggest that we should unilaterally disarm? Some people amongst us say: `Yes'. But, quite obviously, that connotation is ludicrous. I believe that arms control is more appropriate as it applies to the practical world of today. Against this background of complex international politics Australia, with Foreign Minister Hayden leading the way, has spoken out on a number of arms control issues, placing Australia's view before the world so that our position can be clearly understood.

There are those amongst us who throw the word `nuclear' around very loosely; they tie it to everything that is bad. Thus, the issue of the joint facilities, visits of nuclear-powered ships, and even the very presence of the odd United States general or admiral raise their absurd rhetoric to high levels, beyond the bounds of sanity. I say this because the next step is, of course, the dismantling of ANZUS and, further, Australia moving to an unaligned position and complete neutrality.

Let me place Australia's position clearly before the House. We are not pacifists; we are not unaligned. We are part of what is called the Western group of countries and we have a defence capability which is strong enough to deter most would-be aggressors. Therefore, we will continue not only to look after Australia's interests and the interests of the Pacific region but also, beyond that, to have an overview of all issues and to place them in a global context. To suggest in this age that Australia, keeping in mind our geographic position, can be neutral is complete nonsense. Gone are the days when one could realistically hope to isolate oneself from the rest of the world and survive. For example, the joint facilities must be seen in a global context and as a price Australia is willing to pay for the continuation of the ANZUS alliance, the strengthening of the strategic balance and the general position of the Western allies.

ANZUS and Australia's position in the Western world have been attacked many times over the past three decades. However, it must be stated that all the separate issues that surround ANZUS, such as visits of nuclear-powered ships, and indeed the wider question of Australia's security must be taken and looked at as a whole and not separately. An overview is needed, which unfortunately is so often glossed over by some amongst us. Foreign relations and defence planning are by their very nature complex questions with many ingredients coming together to make the whole cake. Our relationship with the United States has matured under this Government. The friendship and the bond between our countries are stronger than ever. Both partners in a relationship must respect the other. It is this respect which holds us together in times of difference, Yes, there will be times when we will disagree with the United States on issues. However, the fact that we can now sit down and discuss sensibly with our friend all aspects of policy is a very big step forward. I commend to the Committee the appropriations for the Department of Foreign Affairs.

In the first place, the dispute did not begin with the claim for a 36-hour week in breach of the prices and incomes accord. The union initially held discussions with Confectionery Manufacturers of Australia Ltd in June 1982 on proposals for a shorter working week. On 1 July Confectionery Manufacturers agreed, on behalf of its members, which included Dollar Sweets, to the introduction of a 36-hour week and the methods of implementing the 38-hour week as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) We would undertake to introduce the 36 hour working week in 1983 with the optimum date being the first full pay period commencing after 30th June.
(ii) The method of implementing the 36 hour working week would be the subject for discussion with your Union prior to its implementation recognising the special needs of small manufacturers.

(iii) The above commitments are made on the basis that it is accepted that the needs of the small manufacturers in the main make a `Shorter Friday every Friday' the only practicable and economically viable way of maintaining smaller business competitiveness when the 38 hour week is operating.
(iv) That the arrangements, many of which are already in operation for the introduction of the 38 hour working week, are implemented without disruption.

On 23 August 1982, the confectionery manufacturers withdrew their offer on the ground that the 38-hour week was now operating and that union industrial action at Dollar Sweets and Fyna Foods (Victoria) Pty Ltd amounted to a non-acceptance of the manfacturers' offer. One has to bear in mind that the prices and incomes accord with the Federal Government was not signed until February 1983. So it was a clear distortion of the facts for the honourable member for Higgins to state that the dispute was in breach of the prices and incomes accord, which at that time did not exist.

However, to get back to the industrial dispute, the workers at the factory were most unhappy at the repudiation of the shorter working hours issue by the confectionery manfacturers. After many meetings with no apparent resolution of the dispute the workers at the factory held a secret ballot which supported the implementation of a 36-hour week and they called on their union to pursue the matter on their behalf. The Confectioners Association approached the Dollaw Sweets management for discussions but the management refused to hold discussions on the issue. As a result of the intransigent attitude of the management, the workers held a several hour stop work meeting. The management continued to refuse to talk to union representatives about the matter and, as a consequence, the workers took strike action. On 18 July 1985, the Managing Director, Mr A. J. D. Stauder, sent a letter to the employees which included the following statement:

The company cannot continue to operate with the threat of stoppages of work hanging over its head. I would like you to read the attached letter. It says, in effect, that you have a week to make up you mind whether you will give the company an undertaking to work normally without strikes or bans. If you are not prepared to give us that undertaking your services will be terminated as from 25th July 1985 at the end of your shift on that day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fascist activity.

—Indeed. Subsequently, there was no attempt by the Managing Director, Mr Stauder, to negotiate with his employees. Instead, he dismissed them and hired strike breakers in their place. As far as the union is concerned, the central issue in the dispute now is the employment of strike breakers and the dismissal of employees taking legitimate industrial action. I have been prompted to inform the House on this matter because of the inaccuracies and ridiculous attacks on the Federal Government contained in the speech by the honourable member for Higgins. Let me end by quoting the view of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on this issue as contained in a Press release of 27 September 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Bill Kelty, today pledged the ACTU's support for the Federated Confectioners Association in its long running battle with Dollar Sweets. The Melbourne confectionery manufacturer.

I refer, of course, to his ill-considered and factually inaccurate attack on the Commission-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —And the honourable member for Parkes has been informed about this contribution, so Opposition members need not start jumping. What does this attack represent?

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: You may or may not be aware that the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) is recovering in hospital today from a serious operation in relation to an injury which occurred last Saturday. If the honourable member persists-

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the Queensland Government's electricity supply legislation, I would suggest that the Human Rights Commission finds itself in excellent company with the many well-known and respected church people of that State. In August of this year it was my privilege to listen to Father Brian Gore at Wollongong Town Hall. During his address, he quite rightly likened the Queensland Government's repugnant legislation to the draconian and repressive legislation of the Philippines. As Father Gore was quick to point out, the two bodies of legislation have much in common; in both cases they constitute a violation of the right to freedom from forced labour, of the right to privacy, of the right to association and of the right to free speech-and these are the very same terms with which the Human Rights Commission criticises the Queensland legislation.

The honourable member for Parkes claimed that the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights was drawn up by overseas socialist countries. That is simply not true. If he had taken the trouble to examine the proceedings of the United Nations General Assembly in 1966 he would be aware that the Western group had a majority and that, in fact, there was considerable resistance to the Covenant from the communist states.

I turn now to the matter of `Irish' jokes and the comments of Professor Blainey on Asian immigration. Again, had the honourable member for Parkes done his homework properly and read the Human Rights Commission's report No. 7, `A Proposal for Amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act to Cover Incitement to Racial Hatred and Racial Defamation', and had he referred to subsequent speeches by both the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Commission, he would know that it has been made quite clear that neither Irish jokes nor Professor Blainey's comments, no matter how tasteless they may be, would be subject to the Commission's proposals. Again, he obviously has not bothered to check the facts. I would advise him to read three of the Commission's reports-Nos. 8, 10 and 13. These reports contain no invitation to circumvent the law but rather an invitation to apply it more humanely or else to change it.

On the question of the Queensland community services legislation, the Human Rights Commission, in its report No. 9, in fact commended the forward steps taken by the Queensland Government in relation to Aborigines living on reserves, but encouraged further action with reference to the right of Aborigines to vote in local government elections and to have control of their own affairs on their own land-surely not too much to expect in a democratic society such as ours! A poor, innocent State fellow brought back a pair of socks from overseas and I notice that he has been taken to task for bringing them back in a courier bag. We have some damned important things to do in Tasmania so I suggest to that dear senator that he leave the matter alone because if he does not he will cop it in Tasmania. He is not in the State Parliament any more. We do not keep off our boxing gloves all the time. We will put them on and he will start to cop a bit of the wrath.

The other person I refer to is a State member of Parliament and his name is Bob Brown. They call him the angel of the conservation movement. He has done enough harm to Tasmania. I think he should start to leave it alone and look after the interests of Tasmanians. One can win glory and fame by running around this country talking to other people but Tasmanian members of Parliament have a job to do and that is look after the Tasmanian people. They should get on with it. If I am ever reincarnated as a politician I would like to come back as a senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because they do not have to put up with all the stuff I have to put up with day after day. Most honourable members have to do a certain amount of work and most whom I know do a dashed lot of work. They have to contend with all the problems in their electorate but some honourable senators-not all of them- seem to walk-
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is reflecting on the character of members of the other chamber.
